I think a way to get Phase 2 out of the way is to invest in bio-computers made from brain cells.

If we are willing to wait, we can grow brains in a lab specially designed to work in machinery and computers, based off our own brains. We would need to watch out that we don't accidentally create a sociopathic murder machine though, because unlike our modern computers, a bio-computer is capable of anything we are on an emotional level, and may very well take pleasure in murdering.

We could also pluck a brain from a body and build it into a computer. We could probably even graft a human into a giant machine and call it a day if we invest enough. It's not as humane, but then again, is growing a brain to serve as a robot slave any less humane?

Rather than colonizing Mars or the moon, I could see us building space stations that rotate to create artificial gravity. That would avoid the hazards found on the surfaces of those bodies, and it would be a more controlled environment. Still, we have a long way to go, but doing this would avoid many of the hazards associated with living on those bodies, and the hazards of traveling to them.

Look at the history of successful and unsuccessful colonization. The only outposts to survive were those with resources in their new environment. Mars has no life-supporting resources. The colony would not be economically self-sustaining, sending raw materials or manufactured products to the organizations that sponsored it.

There's no reason to go there. Anything that can be done from an underground bunker on mars could be done from the comfort of an earth office with breathable air, drinkable water and plenty of delicious food.

The people who are selling the idea of a Mars colony know all this, but they are ignoring these facts for their own financial gain.

Our earthly home is marvelously designed for our thriving and even though we try to ruin it, the ecosystems are still balanced for continued survival.

Be happy for what you have and take care of it. Chicken Little should not define your worldview.

We don't have to send human missions to mars to scout. We already know enough about mars to choose a location which should be near the equator where it is warm and there is more sunlight for the solar panels.

The idea that a Moon base would help a colony on Mars is incorrect. The moon is a gravity well, not an easy rest stop. Also, a moon base would need to have everything delivered to it and it would be competition for funding. Also, any ship leaving earth heading to mars can travel at about 3.5 kms whereas going to the moon it could only go 2.5 kms so a stopover to the moon would waste time and fuel.

Instead of covering the habitat with frozen CO2 (which would require a lot of power and essentially keep the hab inside a freezer) all you have to do is cover the hab with 8 feet of mars regolith to protect against solar radiation and help keep it warm.

Harvesting martian ice for water is dangerous and not necessary. All water brought will be entirely contained inside the habitat and filtered and reused. For the first colony, outside excursions should be kept to a minimum to reduce risk because a pressure loss kills all internal plants and crew in 1 minute.

The less gravity is not really a big problem. It will take time for a crew to adjust to the earth gravity again.

As far as having little contact with the outside world, this is incorrect. They would talk to NASA and their families every day and probably even watch some of the same television shows we watch on earth.

A smart buried habitat would not need a constant supply of resources, parts, and nuclear fuel, whatever you mean by that. The buried hab will grow vegetables in hydroponics and maybe have some mini-fruit trees and tubs with standing vegetables. These plants will remove CO2, produce oxygen, and provide food. Maybe they would have some chickens to produce eggs? All mars base power would come from solar panels and RTG's. So, no nuclear fuel needed.

Full 100% sustainability of an enclosed human habitation is a topic which has been explored among those interested in the concept of an "Arcology," which is technically a related but not identical concept, which gets used as a short-hand to refer to the concept of "100% self-contained and self-sufficient human habitation facility/settlement." If you do some searching on the term "arcology" you'll find some edifying discussions.

The Earth-Moon-Sun system IS a self-contained, and self-sufficient system, or as close to 100% as can be imagined. Over evolutionary time, Earth would never have evolved the way it has had it not been for the various large icy and metalic asteroids populating the rest of the proto-planetary disk and early solar system, so to be more accurate we'd have to say that the "Sol solar system" is 99.9999% self-contained and self-sufficient" (leaving aside a tiny fraction to reflect the chance that the organics or other trace elements which proved to be crucial to life on Earth were introduced after the early Sol molecular cloud began to form into a pre-Solar nebula.

All of which is to say: depending on the time-scale and physical-scale there actually is no such thing as a completely self-contained and self-sufficient ecological framework, but this is primarily an academic point to clarify the caveat that: most arcologies which we might imagine producing within the next 1,000 or so years, will only approach true self-contained self-sufficiency never actually achieve it.

In sum: the degree to which "off-world human habitation or settlement" is self-contained and self-sufficient reflects a set of objective physical and operational parameters which can easily be quantified and aggregated into a score and compared to Earth itself, which achieves 99.99%. Endurance, i.e., the timeframe during which such an off-world settlement can sustain life and normal operations without introduction of supplies or assistance from Earth would also be part of such an assessment.

My understanding is that the ISS achieves only about 1 to 5% self-sufficiency over the time frame of 1 to 2 months. Beyond that endurance range the facilities capacity to sustain human life and normal operations will decline without replenishment from Earth. So, that is the level of our ability to actually do what Musk projects doing: create a colony on Mars.

Personally, I would like to see humanity become a true multi-world species (which is not the same as multi-planet and is a more inclusive concept, which is to say: space habitats may well be a much more sensible approach than "colonizing" any of the presently accessible planets or moons apart from Earth). So I appreciate Musk ostensible vision and goal. But his approach to it is ridiculously simplistic and dumb.

We may eventually have the ability to create self-sustaining self-contained habitats on Earth which in the 6 month endurance range, and that would be a good "first step." A good second step would be to improve reliability, efficiency and redundancy in those initial designs and to extend them to harsh Earthly settings like Antarctica where the prospect of a catastrophe does not equate with death of all personnel. Once such a phase two arcology achieves a high level of self-sustenance for something like 9 to 18 months; it all depends on what systems exist to provide rescue and the timeline of affording such under worst-case scenarios. In short, the settlement should be able to cope with worst-case scenarios long enough to be rescued, whether that means at least 6 months or 24 months of endurance at 99.99% self-contained self-sufficiency.

Once the design works in one of the harshest contexts on Earth--relatively controlled and safe conditions--then it would be replicated/adapted for an orbital habitat. Once that showed success for a sufficient period of time, then the next logical step would be to produce more, bigger and better orbital or LaGrange facilities where centrifugation can provide "normal" gravity and to explore scaling up the designs. A parallel track could also pursue applying the proven arcology technology, designs, principles, protocols and processes to a Moon base, which could then eventually lead to further elaborations for more remote and inhospitable locales.

To me, an average guy, one of the biggest wonders is mankind is our continued unrealistic attitude about colonising space. We might be able to get a few astronauts to survive a several horrific years on the surface of Mars, but to what end? Given the completely inhospitable environment and the logistics in transportation of the sufficient quantity of materials from earth,  a self-sustainable station on Mars to be used as a base for exploring further into space is completely unrealistic . Further, given the seemingly impossible complexities involved, the idea that Mars would be a better base than earth to launch missions elsewhere seems more fantastical still. I love my science-fiction, but when it comes to colonising Mars, and I would love to be proven wrong, but think we have confused fiction with reality.

Correction: We don't actually have the technology to get to Mars, much less establish a colony there. There are still huge challenges, like spacecraft radiation shielding, extreme vision degradation/eventual blindness after 6 months in zero G, damage to body systems that involved fluid (again due to low/zero G), and many technical challenges in tech relating to airlocks, robotics, etc. We might have plausible ideas about how to tackle these problems, but you never have the technology until you actually have it.

The James Webb telescope is a perfect example: You could say we "had" the tech to build and launch the JWST in 1996 when the project began, but we did not, and ultimately it took 25 years and much, much more money than we planned for to make it happen.

tl;dr - There's a big difference between having ideas about how to do something and actually possessing the tech to do it.

Look I know this idea is from a scientific fiction book but it's worth a shot. Send some robots to the asteroid belt. Pick icy ones and push them to Mars. Over time this will speed the core making magnetic fields.

Who's going to pay for it and why would they? We're not talking about the idle chatter of a dilettante billionaire. This would require trillions of dollars with little to no return on that investment. Mars needs to have something Earth wants/needs and it has to be easier/cheaper than alternatives, especially if it's something Earth also has. Humans didn't expand on Earth just for the fun of it. There were social, economic, and political reasons. The Central Plains of the US were actually skipped over for the better soil of the west coast until newer farming techniques were developed and laws were passed that made open range ranching feasible. They could graze cattle on land they technically didn't own, so it became profitable. The fact is that the most uninhabitable places on Earth are more conducive to human life than Mars, the moon, a space station, etc.


Yes, a research outpost might happen, like Antarctica. Permanent colonization is extremely unlikely. First, we don't even know if human birth is possible in such low gravity. Add in the absence of all the necessary bacteria required to support life on Earth. Even if that's all were overcome, there's the fact that people born on Mars or who've lived there for years probably could never return to Earth due to their weakened skeletal systems and an immune system that's compromised due to living in recycled air. This year alone, we're seeing much more severe cold symptoms (non-Covid) just from a year and a half of lockdowns and social distancing. Studies show that kids raised on farms have lower instance of allergies and asthma from those raised in cities, especially without pets in the household from an early age. Like muscles, the immune system needs exercise.


The "technology will overcome" argument doesn't really work because innovation isn't overnight. Look at all the individual missions that were stepping stones to landing on the moon. They had to figure out what worked, what didn't, and then try again. Communication blackouts due to spacecraft position and reentry were "hold your breath" type moments.

From a purely "challenge-oriented" point of view, I understand how such entreprise can be deemed "worth it". But from most other PoV, I completely fail to see how it could be worth it.

The amount of resources and energy necessary to get huge volumes/weights there, to sustain a crew there, and to develop the environment and outpost (absolutely mind-blowing, and obviously substracted from what's available on Earth, which is already limited...), the conditions of living (or rather, surviving), the enormous risks all along, at every litle step, the prior need for a moon base (or an Earth orbital station, I guess)......... and to what extent? Except being able to say that we are a multiplanetary species? Who are we going to brag about it to? There is nothing that humanity absolutely needs on Mars, is it?

Dont get me wrong, on a perfect planet, with an already close to perfect human society, I'd say why not, if we can "afford" it. But to conquer another planet when we cant even share this one in harmony? When hunger, misery, violence are all over our own native world? Sounds futile and/or marked with delusions of grandeur, and/or a seriously messed up sense of priorities... We are not going to find the solution to our problems out there.

Figuring out how to un-greenhouse Venus and terraform Venus is a way better long term idea than Mars.. considering Venus has an extremely robust atmosphere with oxygen already there as well as almost the same gravity as Earth's.. everything about Venus is better than Mars except for the extremely robust atmosphere.. if we can terraform a planet then Venus is the one we should focus on.. I suppose practice on Mars is better for now considering we can't terraform anything yet and could just build some bases underground.. but Venus's atmosphere and gravity is why we should actually focus on long term instead of Mars.. both Mars and Venus have similar magnetic fields with Venus having a slightly stronger one.. but the lack of gravity on Mars might be a long term living situation killer.. we just need to figure out how to release gases on Venus compared to trapping them on Mars, which I think would be easier long term.. but for the next 50-100 years, sure, practice living on Mars and the moon while we figure out how to make Venus a legitimately livable planet we might be able to walk around on without spacesuits..

"Hard but worth it". What makes Mars worth it? There are dozens of places in the solar system where we could build sustainable colonies far more easily and cheaper.

The very best are the asteroids, which we can mine to produce useful ores outside a gravity well while simultaneously constructing deep holes suitable for lovely, safe, rotating habitats - O'Neill cylinders. But if you must inhabit a gravity well, Venus +50K has Earth-normal temperature, pressure, and gravity, and a working ionosphere to keep hard radiation out - the perfect place to build floating cities. Or, if you're really wanting to live underground surrounded by toxic dust, Earth's moon is far closer and offers hardly any less useful gravity than Mars. Or we can bore into any of several water moons surrounding Jupiter and Saturn - you might even discover alien life while you're at it. Or, if terraforming is your chosen career, why not start with the Sahara or Antarctica? Earth is a far easier and more valuable terraforming project than Mars ...

Really, all these places are vastly more hospitable to humans than Mars. So ... what the hell do you mean, "worth it", @Kurzgesagt?

If one of the reasons humanity wants to inhabit mars is to manage overpopulation, it's not gonna solve this issue
1) We co-evolved with the Earth so we're accustomed to its physical and chemical conditions. Mars is completely foreign to us. We'll need to do everything manually. Mistakes are bound to happen. I can't even begin to imagine the casualties that arise from these mistakes.
2) Self-sustaining on mars would not only cost a lot of money but also time. If humans breed on Mars, resources would have to be adjusted constantly. The adults would have to work constantly to survive and to look after their offsprings. Trying to survive on Mars with every technological aid would be like surviving in the wild with nothing on Earth. It's no luxury.
3) Human psychology would deteriorate from always staying inside buildings, not being able to experience the outside world with their senses, severe stress etc.

These come to mind right now. Essentially, everything on Mars are problems that require solving. Everything must be interfered to be fit for humans.

Your video on Mars colonisation is the most realistic I have seen. No nonsensical fantasising about terraforming. However, far from making light of the enormous difficulties as most videos do, you have gone the other way and exaggerated some of the problems, low gravity for example. A 12 stone astronaut wearing the obligatory space suit necessary to go outside his living accommodation would weigh about 6 stone.  There are plenty of 6 stone people on Earth, and they don't suffer bone and muscle wastage. Space suit and accommodation quarters will reduce radiation to acceptable levels. Nitrates for agriculture can be provided by sewage and ammonium nitrate fertiliser. The latter could also be used as an explosive for clearing obstacles. The main hazards will not be on Mars, but on the journey there and back.

I had a pretty wacky idea.

If cryogenic sleep ever becomes a thing (as well as the ability to create wormholes), we could place one end of the wormhole on a ship with a cryogenic sleep chamber in it, and send it off to one of the many Earth-like planets that NASA has found. Since the journey is potentially light-years long, the pilot will place himself/herself into cryogenic sleep for 99.99% of the journey. When he/she wakes up hundreds or thousands of years in the future, he/she will be at least a day or two away from the destination (giving him/her time to prepare a safe arrival). There, he/she will place the wormhole on the planet, and head back to Earth (since the wormhole will probably be too small to fit a ship). By that point, people on Earth could travel to and from the Earth-like planet instantaneously.
And we would repeat the cycle again and again for other places. This process would drastically reduce the time it would take to colonize a planet, or even the entire galaxy!

Perseverance is unmanned, eliminating 95% of the problems a manned mission would have, providing living space and recreation facilities, nutrition, breathable air, and protection from the radiation and the poisonous dust. A manned colony on Mars is science fiction, doable, but prohibitive expensive. It is much more likely that we'll send robots and drones to other planets, moons and asteroids for mining and scientific sampling. There is no other reason for sending humans to mars than stroking ones Ego, though, in the grand scheme, we humans are still just a minor, local, and temporary disturbance. Which brings me to my main point. Step one of colonising other planets, stop killing each other over resources and start working together. In Space we are not Swiss, or Russian, or American, we're human. There is no chance we'll manage this step one.

Because there is no way any person can afford to spend many months on a rotating space station with different levels of gravity, to allow the body to re-adapt to 1G.
NO - Mars will never be a colony, but rather a group of research outposts where people go to complete "tours" of Mars - just as people do in the Antarctic.
If you think of Mars as being the Antarctic, then you are on the right track. You will get a job that might span up to 3 years in total, and when your job is done, you'll return to earth. There will be no option to stay, unless you die on Mars, in which case you will be buried there.
You MAY be permitted to perform more than one tour of Mars, however, and maybe three or even four tours if your radiation exposure levels can be kept to a minimum. But once your exposure reaches a certain point, you will not be allowed to return.
Will there be Martian vacations? Well, maybe! If they exist, they will be very short duration trips where you only spend a week or two on Mars before the long trip home. Probably not worth it for the horrible conditions you must endure during the trip.
Basically, they'll have to endure a quarantine worse than anything seen on Earth. It's easier to clean our planet.

Inspiring as always. Some ideas - based around the premise of no power restrictions. The atmosphere has the right basic components for survival and fractional distillation is one method of separating the 3 basic gases that comprise air. Unlike bio-isolation experiments, we would be in charge of the mixture of gases for human and plant comfort. Aquaponics has potential - fish poo provides for the PPK needs of the plants, but plants do not close the loop. Mars is going to be reliant on supply missions for decades. at least. In terms of plant needs - Mars can supply the perfect light conditions, heat and gas mixture for optimal growth, as long as power is free. Sodium, LED and halides could provide all the light needs for the plants, as well as heat, but the nutrients would have to come from Earth. Most likely bio-tech as well, which is another matter. In dehydrated form these nutrients could be very cost efficient. Aeroponics negates the need for soil - it's only a substrate with a variable properties after all. Roots love the misty environment of aeroponics, the plants grow beyond expectation, and can produce a bumper fruiting stage. It's doable.

A lot of these "dangers" get comically overstated.  The lifetime radiation dose for an astronaut only results in a 4% increased chance of cancer over your entire life, and it is really not technically hard to keep people on a 2 year mission (or longer) from getting that, even with windows.  Perchlorates are also not a deadly toxin.  You wouldn't want to eat the dirt frequently, over many years, and plants will not usually be happy growing in it, but it washes out of the soil with water, which you'll need anyway.

While prefab habitat modules sent from Earth would need to be cylinders and spheres because they have to be strong but light, made with minimum material for the sake of fuel economy for the rockets, that is not true of structures built on Mars, from Marscrete. The pressure difference between the interior and exterior, if our buildings maintained Earth normal sea level pressure inside, would be a maximum of about 14.7 psi, or about the pressure inside a bicycle tire. This is why the ISS cupola can have flat windows and it's not a structural risk. This is also why buildings made from marscrete could, if we desired it, closely resemble normal rectilinear buildings on Earth, big flat windows included (provided they're an inch or so thick). This is one of the factors that makes engineering a 1atm shirtsleeves environment for space, the Moon or Mars so much more forgiving than trying to engineer a 1atm habitat space for use deep underwater, where the pressure differential can be many times more severe.

I think sci-fi has the airlock system for Mars all wrong. You always see the same thing, where there's an airlock that goes bad and you have explosive decompression.

Here's what we should do if we want to do it right. Make concentric rings.
The outer ring would keep out the Martian wind storms.
The next ring would be slightly pressurized with CO2 only, because it's easier to replace on Mars. Vehicles would be parked here.
The next ring would be pressurized a bit more, also with CO2. You could work here, wearing little more than just a helmet. Dust decontamination also occurs here.
The next ring would be pressurized at the same or slightly lower level, with a breathable atmosphere. You could do light work there, or maybe walk around with just a helmet.
The next ring is the inner ring, with normal pressure atmosphere. This is the living space.

One thing I think is missed is the possibility of living underground either in an artificial underground space or in a cave system like lava tubes. Being underground would provide protection from radiation, insulate the base from the martian cold and act as a building material/structure. As you could excavate rooms and such much like a cave house found on earth.

In either case, you could theoretically just use structureless habitats much like a tent without poles where the oxygen would inflate the habitat against the excavated space or cave creating a pressurised space which can then be reinforced from the inside and lived in. This would also allow large indoor spaces and I would definitely build an indoor park to help astronauts stay sane, relax and to provide them with supplemental food. (Who doesn't love a fresh apple?)

I think that the much smaller magnetic field of mars sucks because the solar winds would eventually blow away mars' atmosphere, 600x the speed at which it happens on earth. However, this means that mars could become an industrial paradise for companies that make a lot of co2 emissions :o It's funny how the biggest threat to earth's atmosphere might be what makes mars habitable.

Obviously, for a small settlement on Mars, we need a nice 60 megawatt, modular fission reactor -- for starters.

But it is not a matter of fact that Mars' interior offers no possiblity of geothermal (arethermal?) power. It appears there have been eruptions on Mars within the last mere tens of thousands of years -- so it isn't totally dead, at least in the area of Cerberus Fossae. ... and it's uncontroversial that there has been volcanism on Mars in the last 3 million years. So -- because volcanism has always been less frequent on Mars than on Earth (in addition to activity having steadily gone down over the last couple billion years) -- it's not surprising we find ourselves at a point in time between any activity.

Volcanism on Mars is exclusively like intracontinental hotspot volcanism on Earth, pretty sure, and when was the last time we had mantle plume-generated explosive rhyolitic volcanism or flood basalt extrusive volcanism on Earth? A long time ago. And yet Yellowstone is still nice and toasty warm.

Probably there are some slushy magma chambers still. Although they are likely pretty deep on Mars. Buts it's not totally impossible that geothermal energy production could end up being a thing, at some point.

Seriously, there is nothing on Mars of any interest, it is a completely dead rock, through and through. Even its core has cooled and solidified. Humans cannot survive there, not even in a habitat. As, even in a habitat the humans that went there would be blasted by solar radiation on a regular basis. Here on Earth we have a magnetosphere that protects us from such radiation. Without that our planet would quickly look like Mars. On Mars all it would take to kill every human on it is a single solar flare. Here on Earth that would be practically nothing. On Mars it would just be the end, full stop.

Not only that, but the soil there is straight up deadly. Even if the planet was terraformed(impossible by the way), the soil there would still keep people from going outside. You can't breathe it in, hell, you can't even get it on your skin.

No way to make food, no way to where to get drinking water.

Humans will die so fast that in order to keep a presence on Mars we will have to send millions of people there in a never ending string of missions. One mission takes off here and there better be a rocket waiting to go, to be launched immediately afterward.

Oh, and that isn't even mentioning the perfectly normal rape and murder that will have to be done, in the name of survival. Oh yeah, this just got dark, real dark. But true nonetheless.

See, humans can't survive on Mars. Not as we are today. We evolved to survive on THIS planet, specifically. We are specialized to live here and ONLY here. And at that, we have only actually evolved to live on exactly 30% of this planet's surface, as we have not yet evolved to survive in our oceans, which makes up the remaining 70% of the Earth's surface.

But we do know how to breed and evolve. But you are not going to like it... And "Gruesome" doesn't even come close to describing what is necessary.

The very moment a female reaches puberty, no matter her age, she will have to be impregnated, even she doesn't want to, even if she doesn't fully understand what is going on. And the males, age is irrelevant, as long as they are the strongest against the Mars environment, will have to be the only ones to do it. And they too will have to do it, even if they don't want to, even if it is against their will. On Earth we call that rape. On Mars that will just be survival.

Further, all of those that are weak against the Martian environment must be euthanized. As you just simply can't have them breeding in the genepool. You MUST move forward. You cannot afford to have any accidents, no unsanctioned breeding. Such a thing would have to be punished by death. Here on Earth we call that murder. On Mars that will just be survival.

All of this with the sole goal of breeding a human, the first human, that can actually survive in the Martian environment. A human that is immune to the Martian regolith, can survive in the massive dust storms, can breath in the zero air atmosphere and is immune to the raw solar radiation. And more.

Personal feelings, emotions, desires, none of those will hold any meaning on Mars once people get there with no way of getting back. It will be either breed up then die, or just die.

The first creature Earth that crawled out of the ocean and onto the shore, it immediately died. But they kept on trying and eventually one survived. That one eventually found another one and they kept on fucking till they had babies that could live on land. And so on and so forth. That is how Mars will be.

I have looked at a lot of videos about colonizing the moon & Mars. And I haven't found any with my same ideas. I think we should set up a moon colony on earth. We should have inflatable domes, which we cover with 3D printers with simulated moon mortar. The domes should be connected to each other by inflatable tunnels covered with simulated moon mortar. There should be living quarters, hydroponic green houses, gardens with garden soil for recreational gardening, a 5 acre pasture with one inch of garden soil and one inch of grass turf, a park with artificial turf and with small sections of real grass turf, and maybe even a very small zoo. All the domes will have plastic floors so no water is lost. Condensation forming on the ceilings will be drained into the water supply. All the domes will be blown up with compressed air from earth and will have a refresh system, which will refresh the air and maintain the air pressure. Humidity, Temperature will be maintained by humidifiers, heaters, fans and coolers. Light will be provided by multi-color LEDs, mostly white. Power will be supplied at first by solar power, and later by nuclear or fusion power. There will be a bull, a cow, two sheep, and two goats, two chickens, two turkeys, two fish, and two rabbits. There will also be pets, two dogs, two cats, two bunnies, etc. (and maybe a small zoo) All of this will be set up by astronauts and robots before the colonist arrive.

The first colonist will be 5 fathers and 5 mothers, and 90 babies. The parents will be good parents, gardeners, farmers, zoo keepers, teachers, etc.. During the first two years an exact duplicate facility will be built on the moon. When the babies are two years old, they will move to the moon and live on the moon. Or if it is proven that they will be too young to travel to the moon than the facility on earth will be added to, to accommodate 10 more parents and 90 more babies. The two year olds would move into the new addition. Every two years the facility will be either added to, or 100 people will move to the moon. This plan will allow the kids to grow up in the isolation of the colony, and will make it easier for them to live in the isolation of the colony on the moon. And will allow them to grow up on the moon and be better able to adjust to the lower gravity on the moon, although some artificial gravity maybe eventually provided. This artificial gravity will especially be good for the parents. The kids will have everything in the facility to keep them occupied and entertained. Also they could have some books, movies, games, etc., especially adapted for them, being careful not give them anything that would make them feel isolated.

After 20 years there could be 2000 people living on the moon, most of whom grew up on the moon. This program could be speeded up so in 20 years there could be 4000, 6000, or 8000 people living on the moon.

This program could be simultaneously done to colonize Mars so we could have 2000 people on the Moon and Mars at the same time. For the moon we could send supplies every month, but for Mars we could only send supplies every 26 months. So I suggest we send 10, 20, or 30 rockets to Mars every 26 months all at the same time.

We could have several refueling stations along the way to mars and orbiting mars so rockets could refuel along the way to mars and right before landing on mars so the empty rocket would have enough fuel to take off again, refuel in space and return to Earth. Eventually the moon and Mars could export minerals or small expensive items that were assembled on the moon or Mars, like jewelry, iphones, iwatches, etc. Or grown on the moon like caviar, marijuana, etc.

If you want to read some hard sci-fi about the colonization of Mars, I highly recommend Kim Stanley Robinson's Mars trilogy.

Book 1, Red Mars, addresses all of the colonization issues in this video and more. Book 2, Green Mars, addresses societal conflicts and additional technical issues. Book 3, Blue Mars, moves into societal development and politics, both within Mars and between Mars and Earth.

The entire trilogy is a very engrossing read. The science is sound for most of the trilogy and plausible for the other bits. There's romance, betrayal, intrigue, robots, a secret organization, terraforming via comet. Hands down the best hard sci-fi I've ever read.

I think that an underground Mars Colony, at least for the time being, would be the best route to take.  it only takes something like a half a meter of packed dirt to almost completely block radiation.  The idea will be to set up a functional Mars colony.  Not to wander around on the surface.  Yes there is some great science  to be done on the surface of Mars and if we have a functional Mars Colony, that science would be facilitated easier.  Sadly, it woulod not be on the "Must Do" list of the first few trips.  I would think that setting up a  <del>successful</del> Mars colony is still outside of our current technology base.   To tackle something a difficult as a Mars Colony, we need to take baby steps.  First Things First:  A Lunar Base where we tackle problems we might face on Mars a lot closer to home.  Then after that the creation of highly complex Multifunctional Robotic Workers, essentially a Swiss Army Robot that has real problem solving capacity (Ie meaning it could survive for at least eight minutes on Mars without Human Instruction no matter what the situation.)   Then, after your Robotic Army of Doom makes an underground lair for your peoples that is powered by a Nuclear Reactor that wont meltdown for at least twenty five years, you are all set.  Easy Right?

Mars itsn't Antartica, so don't make any comparison. The isolation of the initial crew and the hard routine (and probably boring) it's because how NASA design "missions". Colonization it's not a "mission" that requires a strict protocol; think about the european colonization of America, Africa, etc. We need certain amount of freedom for iniciatives, even in a extreme hostile environment like Mars. Habitats could be made by using the regolith as local concrete (there is studies about it) inside the lava tubes or below ground. Boring Company of Musk exist for a reason. Acuaponics it's the best solution for now for food production and for energy local production of methane, not only for refuelling rockets back to Earth but for power plants.. Far beyond terraforming (for me it's no sense) it's more plausible modify our genetics, medicine in order to adapt our bodies in this conditions. Actually there is a proposal of use a syntetic version of melanonin with selenium to block radiation, as outer layer for space suits, vehicles, even as a "space sunscreen".

Being stuck inside the same building, for months on end, with no human contact aside from the people in with you.. 1) lack of windows ... we have thin-screen monitors we can already use as faux windows here on earth. Just put several of those inside as "windows" and the occupants can have them be windows to any environment of their choosing.. snowy mountains, tranquil streams, etc. With proper environmental systems, you can simulate a "cool breeze" coming from an "open window" or a slow warm sunny window with some radiant heat.


2) the real reason Mars colonization is annoying.. there's just no tangible reason to be there. The resources there would be a PITA to mine. There's nothing there that really gives it purpose to be there and deal with overcoming all the obstacles. Eventually maybe the cost/benefit will hit a point where colonizing mars will be useful, but right now there's just no reason to do it except for the "great, we did it" experience.. and after that the folks would get bored and want to come home since they're not doing anything productive (the science they do would run out over time and they'd be sitting around twiddling their thumbs.) Going to mars is like going to the North Pole... ok, great, we did it.. but there's very few reasons to stay.

Simple explanation for everything, courtesy of The Martian..

Use oxygen and water reclaimers to have continual supplies, use treated faeces as manure for plant bacterial growth in the soil (separate for each person though), line the habitats and suits with a thin layer of lead to prevent radiation poisoning and use a mix of high energy efficient solar power and nuclear power for energy.

Have multiple air locks to allow for external ventures while one is being repaired if damaged, have a decontamination area for the dust, the perchlorates have been mathematically proven to be non-lethal, and even if they were, just wash the dirt by boiling the salt out of the dirt. Grow the plants inside, where a continental power supply and controllable environment allow for maximum plant growth. Start with potatoes as they are the most versatile food and have pretty much every thing humans need except for calcium. Build a refinery to extract the iron in the Martian soil and use it to build more.

I could envision terraforming two planets simutaneously.  Massive tanker/distillation ships would siphon off atmosphere while orbiting Venus via some sort of jet pump siphoning arrangement.  The same nuclear plant would use a portion of the harvested material as ejection propulsion to maintain orbits and make interplanetary trips.  On the years long voyages, distillation plants would extract valuable commodities like water and oxygen, carbon could even be extracted as a construction material.  Once at Mars, the tankers would eject their cargos to bouy up the thin Martian atmosphere while simutaneously increasing the planet's temperature by means of the greenhouse effect. The tankers would reserve enough mass to return to Venus and repeat the cycle until a viable atmospheric density is acheived.  Mar's mass would be increased as we mine the asteroid belt.  Exhausted asteroidal waste would bombard the surface in controlled sequences (goodbye, Ceres).  Though the increase in mass would be minute, the heat of the collisions may have positive benefits releasing water vapor trapped in soils and fusing large amounts of dust.  I'm hesitant to believe Mars has enough gravitational mass to maintain a permanent atmosphere, so periodic shipments would be brought in to refresh mass stripped away by solar winds.  I could see earth's moon also given a thin atmosphere which may moderate the temperature and pressure extremes there as well.

This is why it's better to terraform Mars first. However, even if we knew how, we'd have to sacrifice one of two things: the amount of force our bodies have to deal with on the planet, or a breathable atmosphere. There may be a way to do both, but it's currently unknown, and this biggest reason is Mars's size. Venus would actually be easier to terraform, but it being closer to the sun means it's more dangerous for long-term habitation. We could somehow find a way to make an artificial planet, but making one of any significant size would mess up the other orbits in the solar system.

So here's a better idea: Protect Earth, explore it as much as possible, and for everything else there's virtual reality pods that automatically regulate our bodily needs...if we keep our bodies at all. Considering current research into neurotechnology, we might master that before we ever figure out how to do terraforming properly.

This would so much easier to do with a base orbiting Mars. It solves two of the problems mentioned immediately: Deliveries are much much easier because you're not at the bottom of a gravity well. The simple reality is that until we have created a novel as-yet undiscovered form of energy creation, bases at the bottom of gravity wells just aren't that feasible unless the surface is basically innately livable.

As for the radiation problem, we need to consult the Japanese. Shinzo Abe's government has managed to exponentially - literally - decrease the half-lives of radioactive isotopes . Chernobyl is still declared uninhabitable, while the area around the Fukushima Dai-ichi Nuclear Plan has been declared "restored" just 8 years following the explosion - all while the meltdown of the reactor continues. Japanese government data suggests that in the 8 years since the Fukushima nuclear accident, the Japanese population - especially that around Sendai - has developed almost superhuman resistance to radiation, so much so that Japanese nuclear workers are permitted to receive a whopping 250 mSV radiation per year. The average pansie-ass nuclear worker only stomachs 20 mSv per year, and natural background radiation is just 3 mSV. The Japanese have to be doing something right. Planetary terraforming  levels.
       Level 1- A self sustainable outpost with a contained atmosphere, and residence.
       Level 2- A large inclosed environment with its own independent ecosystem controlled with advanced genetic programming and internal weather system.
       Level 3 - Making the planets surface as habitual as Earth’s.

Electric solar plants.
       Using gene editing to put the electricity generating capability found in electric eels into a plant or algae so that the hybrid organism can use solar energy to produce an electric current from photosynthesis. 

Ark Drive.
      Storing the sequences of alleles for each  of the available organism genomes and long the data into secure servers.  This would effectively creating a library of atgc combinations which one could use to clone said organisms from the sequences into an egg or seed that would become an embryo and so on.   By doing this we could grow a baby blue whale on mars with having to bring living blue whales through space to Mars, we could just send a copy of the DNA sequence via radio signal across planets. One could just send over the data and use a synthetic womb to grow the whale. 
        Current biotechnology is not advanced enough to accomplish such a feat, but the current challenge shouldn’t prevent the collection, sequencing, and storage of the blue prints for all variants of life. The film Jurassic Park played with similar ideas.  The amount of money that would be needed to fund the pursuit of this goal would be great but the resulting data base would have larger ecological and technological value.
           A library of the genomes of all available organisms so we can in the future can "clone" species that are going to go extinct today, granting it the ability to reproduce a synthetic ecosystem without having to ship live animals across the vast expanse of space. 

The lunar drove hives.
      Using self replicating mining machines to industrialize the Moon’s surface without needing manual labor from astronauts.  Send a small amount of solar power mining machines to the moon to mine materials to build more mining machines and a factory.  They would need to be controlled either by a basic AI or by human pilots on Earth. As they collect more materials by mining and refilling the ore the drone the dig up from beneath them so they can manufacture more drones.

I know I will get a lot of flak for this but: We cannot colonize Mars. So many things have to go right, so many things can go wrong, and so many things that might go wrong are absolutely unforeseeable. Landing on the moon is child’s play compared to sending people to Mars and keeping them there. How on earth are we going to pay for such a decades-long project when Trump can‘t even scrape thr comparatively puny 20 billions together to build his wall? Well, maybe the money earned with future „space“ tourism, i.e. letting the superrich circle the moon which is right on our doorstep, might be put towards the venture, but what for?
Just think this through: for the first settlers life on Mars would be so infinitely dreary and burdensome that even the most resilient spirit will eventually be forced to admit that the Mars adventure is a futile enterprise. The wing of a humble housefly, the tiniest feather of a bird are marvelous constructions that are more precious than anything that we can hope to discover on Mars, examples of the trillions and trillions of evolutionary wonders to be found on our home planet - all for free, albeit largely unacknowledged, and taken for granted by most of us. Why do we yearn for settling a barren, cold, dusty rock that is far less hospitable than the summit of Everest? Has anybody ever tried to imagine the incredible, never-felt-before homesickness that settlers will experience, with a dim sun on the horizon, their home planet practically invisible and totally out of reach? No amount of training we can do here on Earth can ever prepare anybody for this kind of psychological horror. And there are countless other aspects that make the Mars adventure a questionable enterprise.
By all means, let‘s attempt it anyway; and if we fail miserably - and even in the very unlikely event that we succeed - it will definitely increase our appreciation for the miraculous planet we already have and so obviously do not deserve. Let‘s just hope it won‘t be too late by then.
And for the fun of it: Let‘s just assume a Mars colony can be established and children are born and raised there. Inevitably, they will learn about Planet Earth and see pictures and documentaries - will they not ask why the hell their parents ever left such a wonderful and varied place?

7:06 That little face is a reference to the original Doom game from 1993. That face was to be a sort of Status representation, as it changed and looked around depending on what current effects were on the Player, how hurt the Player was, etc. Said face was supposed to act as a sort of representation of the main characters current face, the main character being unnamed and often referred to as Doom Guy or the Doom Marine. The face would grow increasingly bruised and bloodied as the Player was damaged, and would eventually close his eyes and die when the Player's health reached a Null Value. In some ports of the game, if the Player managed to get a "Gibbed Death" (Meaning if the player was crushed or exploded), the face itself would also explode in violent 90's pixelation. It is also worth noting my favourite expression made by him, when the Player picked up a new weapon, he would display an iconic malicious grin.

Here's a thought: Algae, in certain forms, is very biologically resilient to many chemicals and hazardous radioactive materials -- and even naturally breaks some radioactive materials down into harmless isotopes. Algae is also cheap to come by -- eutrophication is already a huge environmental problem in some places, and they would love if people came by and took the algae away. I think that algae could naturally be most resistant to a Mars environment -- that or tardigrades, but I don't know if tardigrades are edible while I know for sure algae is. Furthermore, because algae is photosynthetic, it will breathe in the carbon dioxide and release breathable oxygen into the atmosphere. It becomes an even more viable option since it fixes multiple problems.

So much bad information in this video. Solar radiation can be dealt with by placing your habitat in permanent shadow (ie a mountain). It's radiation coming directly from the Sun you have to worry about.

Food CAN be grown outside in pressurized greenhouses made from UV repellent plastics like the ones found in sunglasses. Perchlorates literally wash out of soil with regular water so organic waste, pressure and water are all you need to make Martian soil (no need to create indoor soil factories). There are frozen water reserves all over the planet just a few feet down in most places so no need to be at the poles.

What a Venus cloud city has going for it: The atmosphere around Venus provides more options than Mars air or atmosphere. The gravity for Venus is much more similar to earth than Mars. There would be far more solar power to exploit near Venus than Mars. And the distance from earth to Venus is closer than earth to Mars.

All Mars has going for it apart from its popularity and a more habitable surface is a more similar day length to earth and 2 moons rather than none.

You are missing the point of colonizing other planets. It’s not because we are abandoning earth, it’s because we care about it, and because that is simply what life does. It grows, it’s consumes resources, it gains complexity, and it spreads. From the smallest bacterial cell, all the way up to the oldest trees and biggest animals, that is the basic directive of life. We are smart, and much more complicated than other life here on earth, but that doesn’t quite mean we can just opt out of basic life tendencies. Not unless we wish to go extinct. Yes, we can absolutely do things better on earth. And we definitely should. But if we want to continue as a species, colonizing mars is probably one of the most important feats there is. Even with the most efficient technology possible, earth will at some point be unable to support such a large amount of life. Planets are basically a host, and life is the bacteria. But that doesn’t mean we have to be a deadly bacteria. We can be symbiotic. We just have to spread out to equalize or lower the proportion of resource usage and growth rate. When you say that we should just stay on earth and forget about mars, you are saying we should all stay on earth, continue destroying it, and die. Earth will recover, but we will all suffocate. Keep being eco friendly, and doing everything you can. But that isn’t a permanent solution. It’s a temporary stabilizer, giving us the time we need to expand before it’s too late. Being pro-mars means being pro-earth, and pro-human. Since you are all living beings, and you all consume resources just like everything else, this outlook is your most primitive and necessary duty. Remember that next time you fight against colonizing mars.

TL;DR - Protect Earth first, otherwise, nothing is possible. There is no planet B.


I love Kurzgesagt, and have been subscribed since the first video. But recently they seem increasingly obsessed with colonisation and "progress". Overproduction and colonisation are arguably the worst parts of humanity and I don't think they should be spoken about with such enthusiasm. Humanity will never reach Mars unless we first solve the problems we have here on Earth. How do we pool resources to sustain a second planet when we can't fairly pool resources to sustain the Earths population?


Mars, as stated in this video, is a horrible place to go, and terrible at sustaining life. Earth, however, is a haven, in fact, THE haven for humanity, we thrive here. Earth has everything we need, Mars has nothing. Yet this type of colonisation and progress, (through extreme capitalism); is destroying Earth (a haven for humanity), turning it to a desolate wasteland; in order to go to Mars (a desolate wasteland) and (maybe) turn it into a haven for humanity. This is the craziest gamble we can make.


Mars will never give us what Earth has, and making videos like this encourages thoughts of giving up hope on Earth in order to reach for the stars. These type of videos encourage over-production and waste of resources. We will never have the capacity for space travel without first solving the environmental and socio-political problems we face on Earth.


I don't want to take a Nihilist approach to the climate, and so I will say this; humanity can do great amazing things, and we have in the past, but every amazing thing we have done before was possible because of the bountiful resources on Earth. We will do amazing things more, but only if the first of those amazing things is to protect and re-think how we treat the greatest gift we have - Earth.


I would love to see a Kurzgesagt video about how to save Earth, and how much we owe our planet. Because as far as we look, we will never find a place as well suited to humanity as here. Protect Earth first, otherwise, nothing is possible. There is no planet B.

Radiation info given in this video is not accurate. To this day we have low quality data on radiation exposure and human effects etc. Aside from Hiroshima/Nagasaki and Chernobyl, we don't have much else. There is plenty of evidence to suggest that humans are able to adapt to higher radiation environments if the level is brought up gradually enough. Examples here on earth are commercial pilots, people living high up in the mountains or near various other places with much higher than average levels of radioactive minerals present in the soil. This needs to be studied far more before high quality guidelines can be formed. Our current guidelines are "high paranoia" until we know better.

Could we try and rebuild the Martian Magnetosphere?

As you know the sun emits a powerful solar wind (cosmic radiation) that is so devastating it can strip away the atmosphere from a planet. The thing preventing this from happening to Earth is its magnetosphere. A field generated by the spining core of the planet. No spinning core, no magnetosphere.

Mars lost its magnetosphere when the planet itself died (roughly) 2 billion years ago and the core ground to a halt. After time, mars lost its atmosphere because of the solar winds. Could we rebuild the vast expanses of the res planet's cold mountainous deserts by restarting its core?

If so, could stupidly powerful magnets be enough to manipulate the metals in the martian core back into rotation?

This romanticizing of Mars needs to stop. No matter what we enjoy telling ourselves, it's not a second Earth and it's not a paradise waiting to happen. It's a desert. An endless, freezing, irradiated desert, a wasteland ravaged by solar wind and cosmic radiation. Just because it's considered our best candidate for possible expansion doesn't mean much, considering the rest of the planets in the solar system are either balls of ice or balls of fire. The time and cost required to colonize - let alone terraform - Mars surpasses what humanity as a whole can spare a million times over. So let's keep our expectations grounded on reality.

IMO Mars would actually be better to colonise than the Moon.

Radiation levels on the moon are higher than those on Mars. The Martian atmosphere is able to stop some radiation from the sun, but the moon has no atmosphere to stop radiation.

Lunar dust, like Martian dust, is very fine and electrostatic, and would be just as damaging to machinery, electronics and human lungs.

Mars has 1/3 of Earth’s gravity, however the moon has 1/6 gravity, which would lead to greater muscle and bone loss

Subsurface water may exist all over Mars, while on the Moon the only surface/subsurface water is near the poles

While solar power would be less efficient on Mars, it still would be a viable energy source. Nuclear fuels such as thorium also exist on Mars

The main advantage the Moon has, however, is that it is far closer to Earth, thus travel and communication times would be far shorter. Once you got there, though, Mars would be a more hospitable environment for colonisation

If you REALLY want to colonize Mars it would be far more practical to start with a robust orbital infrastructure.

Perhaps attached to one of the moons, the issue at that point is you will likely discover that a comfy orbital habitat with free access to space and cheap travel to the rest of the system is far more attractive than dropping into a gravity well just to scratch a living out of a toxic world!

The only thing I can thing of that would make sense for a habitat would be caves.
With the advancement of AI we could have robots alter existing caves with much less need for 4 hour intervals between operations. For instance, scan the dimensions of the cave and tell the robot to change an existing area withing certain parameters. This could go on four hours, days or even weeks before the need for another set of commands. (again, with well developed AI)
 Once we have a good knowledge-base of the chemical makeup of the cave, we could develop a spay-on, protective layer if needed, to prevent exposure. ...probably polymer based but whatever is effective. This way we can have a much larger habitat than could conceivably be carried to Mars, with the need for only two artificial walls. At minimum, one for the entrance, exit and ventilation (if needed) and another to complete the ventilation cycle and/or to connect the devices that produce the atmosphere for the habitat and collect or evacuate depending on the needs of the inhabitants.
 The Biosphere II experiments have been somewhat successful in teaching us how to make a closed cycle system using plants & animals except that they massively screwed up by allowing the concrete to be exposed to the system which leached oxygen from the enclosure. Having the habitat deep under ground also mean less fluctuations in temperature and air pressure.
I think simulating an earth environment in a Martian cave is the cheapest route with the least likelihood for cabin fever but it still poses challenges we haven't solved yet.

Mars colonization will not be possible without a largescale international effort. Colonizing other planets and overcoming the subsequent dangers/challenges inherent within such an endeavour is vital for the long-term survival of mankind. However, it will require global cooperation and that's a big problem.

If we do colonize Mars, however, I agree that we should build our habitat underground. I feel like any advanced sentient race would choose to build underground dwellings for safety. Not only can it shield you from a variety of surface catastrophes, but also somewhat hides your existence - gives you a tactical advantage over your opponents/competition. If a civilization cannot be externally detected, then it cannot be destroyed by external means. It also means you can ambush invading forces.

Plus imagine if you're civilization also had large hangers hidden on other planets within a solar system. The moment an attacking force lands of the planet, the native civilization can rise up from underground and ambush the invading species, then a distress call could be triggered and as the invading force turns all of its orbital weapons of the surface, the fleets of stored ships(presumably with crews) would arrive behind the attacking fleet and cut them off entirely.

Spinning living centers would use tons of energy, and seem ripe for catastrophe.
They'd be at an angle, which sounds even more difficult and dangerous.
A meteor that wouldn't destroy a normal building of that size, could spell disaster.
I doubt it could even be truly fail-safe.
That doesn't mean we cannot go to Mars ever, we just can't stay long. Less of a colony, more of a research outpost.
Perhaps space stations orbiting mars, with space elevators(which could use the low gravity to our advantage), could work for a colony. Spinning is safer and easier in space, and having a planet nearby would probably help out a space colony.
But with a large number of satellites, Kessler Syndrome threatens them.
One satellite could break apart, destroying more, eventually becoming a field of scrap bullets.
(The high speed of satellites, is because at orbital heights, at least for current Earth satellites, most of the gravity is still there. You just move really, really fast to deal with that. This is why balloons would make merely a dent in the mass cost of launching things into orbit. I used to wonder about that until I looked it up.)
Best to have a solid foundation, literally and metaphorically.

This is an illusion. Why to colonize this cold desert planet without enough gravity and atmosphere - without a magnetic shield so that the cosmic radiation will again and again turn away any terraforming effect towards a better atmosphere? Because of thin atmosphere, every colonist or glassed habitate on the surface will be a fragile target of micro meteorites. If the colonization starts, this planet will be a giant money pit and cemetry of naive enthusiasts.

What I think is more likely to happen first is that someone will land robots on a small but resource rich asteroid and, ever so gently, push it into in earth's orbit where it can be mined for several years. Whoever pulls this off will become the first trillionaire, and can use that money to fund further space exploration. The  "age of exploration" in the 15th and 17th centuries was led by people who were already rich, but were greedy for more. Whoever grabs the first low hanging fruit of the space economy could kick off a gold rush for space resources and advance spacefaring technology in the process.

I'm totally along for the ride in your description of how horrible these first few steps will be, but IN NO WAY do I make the leap that you seem to make in how these same problems magically disappear and get us to the step where it's "all worthwhile" - whatever that means.  I don't see what changed. To just scratch the surface, no one will ever be able to spend meaningful time "outside", we certainly won't be able to enjoy a sunny day, there's no "fresh air" to breath, we'll basically be morlocks living in a synthetic underground cave. What about our dogs and cats and other animals? Do we bring them along and subject them to this horrific life? On the other hand, who the hell wants to live without dogs being around (not me that's for sure). Anyway, I'm digressing, the point is, I do NOT see this happening.  Seriously, what's THE POINT!? I don't buy the "someone wants to do it argument" - it's costly and wasteful, who's going to foot the bill for this elaborate suicide run? We've evolved for hundreds of millions of years to live here, on Earth, with all it's joys and wonders and gifts that you are mostly unaware of as you muddle through your day. IMHO the fantasy of traveling to other planets is going to forever remain in the realm of sci-fi books and movies. We need to accept that we're here for the long haul - let's make THIS work and save our effort and $$ on this ill thought out fantasy.

Kursgesagt, Many to most of the problems you list can be solved easily, with one simple change. The survive-ability of any human on Mars, particularly in the early attempts, is , of course, doubtful. Send older people. Do not intend at first to return them. Much of your provisions and supposition is based upon explorers going home. Please forgive me for using cold logic, but that is an energy, equipment intensive,, uh,, dumb idea.

If money is the fuel,, and it most certainly is,, If it cost one dollar to get a human to Mars, the cost of returning that same one person is 7 or 8 dollars. And ESPECIALLY in the earliest attempts, where a launch of 5 tons of beans could be done for 8 or 10 cents,, returning the 'used computer' to Earth is impractical, expensive, unprofitable, and just plain wrong. Realistically look at the odds of success for either idea. 1/3 of all Mars missions have utterly failed,, that 1/3 failure rate will not magically disappear because now we have live humans aboard. On the surface of Mars for an extended stay, i/3 to 1/2 of all explorers will die of a dust storm, a suit leak, fall from a cliff, a power coupling failure,,, ,, and then comes the big one. Launching from Mars to return to Earth,, with zero support infrastructure in place on the ground. Zero rescue possible. Zero ground control. Zero maintenance or repair facilities. 2/3rds failure rate minimum. So look at the cold hard facts and statistics. Under your plan there and back, if you send 6 missions of 5 people each. a total of 5 to 7 people will ever make it home,, and those radiation damaged by 4 years of in flight and on the ground. 23 to 25 dead. Under a no return plan, at 1/2 the cost, send the same 30 people,, but older explorers, 20 will land safely and 10 will still be alive and working 5 years later.

So, send older people. Bone density issues, if staying, are a non issue. Radiation and cancer are less risky for an older person. Tougher, mentally and physically. The minimum age for going to Mars should be 55 years old.

Mars would have to be domed over... if the temperature rises to a comfortable level, whatever good volatiles are present will start to escape mars even if an artificial magnetic field is employed to resist solar weathering. The gravity well is just too small for a blue mars to last very long. Terraforming existing planetary bodies just isn't very efficient use of what's there. Venus could be terraformed much easier. Just block out the sun completely until it cools off, use the blocked sunlight to power operations in space, use the existing heat on Venus for powering air colonies (like geo-thermal generators), and then when its within range of earth normal, use the giant eclipser to artificially create a more suitable day/night cycle on the planet. But realize that Venus won't ever be a water world unless we smack it with giant snowballs. And whatever is wet on Mars will start to melt into space if we heat it up to earth normal.

It would be so much easier to build giant structures in space, use centrifugal gravity to simulate earth normal, and just nudge them out of the way of any incoming bogies, natural or artificial. Controlling a completely artificial environment is preferable to terraforming for human habitation, no quakes, no volcanos, & if it's done right, no flooding. It's highly efficient, it's comparable to driving a car versus taming a horse. These planets are wild mustangs, you can break them, saddle them up, but they'll always be a little wild, naturally unpredictable & perhaps desperate to reestablish the natural states that we've found them in. We can do better than that. I'm not opposed to going to Mars or Venus, I just see them more as a place of limited scientific research, and perhaps to make spare parts for space cities than places that need to be terraformed because keeping them terraformed will be nearly as hard & expensive as terraforming them in the first place & even then the environment will have its extremes, all the kind of things that create absolute disasters on earth. In space, the only environment in space we have to master is the heliosphere & and there's plenty of things we can do, and relative positions we can park on in the solar-system where the future majority of humanity could orbit in extreme safety from the heliosphere. & as opposed to sending our best & brightest to distant worlds, on world living is where they will very likely send people they can't stand.

Mars has almost no atmosphere due to its low gravity and lack of a magnetosphere, meaning normalization can't be maintained without constant resource expenditure. Adding water and other compounds to the atmosphere would generate an enormous amount of static and lightning, essentially turning Mars into a giant plasma-ball. The constant, extreme temperature shifts and lack of sunlight will always prevent most vegetation from growing, even if we somehow detoxified ALL of the soil.

So, colonizing Mars isn't just a bad idea, it's attempted suicide. We need to put our resources into developing space-faring colonies by harvesting asteroids and comets, preferably close to the sun. From there, we can build Dyson swarms and artificial planets.

Sounds like Kurzgesagt has the space colonization timeline more or less figured out.

Step 1: Phase 2 of moon colonization (semi-permanent settlement)
Step 2: Phase 1 of Mars colonization (manned mission + unmanned recon missions)
Step 3: Phase 3 of moon colonization (self-sufficient permanent settlement)
Steps 4 and 5 (order unclear): Experimenting with building a Dyson Swarm using Mercury, phase 2 of Mars colonization
Steps 6 and 7 (order unclear): Construction of Dyson Swarm begins on Mercury, Phase 3 of Mars colonization
Step 8: Large-scale mining of the asteroid belt, phases 1 and 2 of colonizing moons of outer planets
Step ?: Interstellar travel, interstellar colonization

First off, the answers are right in front of us. No civilization before us has ever succeeded. The arrogance to think we are the first people from Earth to do this. With how much time has passed, and all the great empires that rose and fell. WE, this generation, are the ones to piece history together, and colonize space. We should have been born into a colonized solar system already. NOBODY has ever made it off the planet? You can't believe people were just thumbing their ass for thousands of years on record and 100's of millions+ off the record. Applying a time line to the earth period, is also a fallacy. WE HAVE NO IDEA.
Also, based on the simple facts of human behavior, If we could get there, we would. Greed, strategic position, ect. No country would hesitate. Whoever gets there first wins the Earth. You spend a few hundred million to get back trillions after some mining, but nobody does it? Stop. Nasa will just string this entire generation along for another 50 years, and repeat with the next generation. Passing the torch to Elon is just another reset. There's still people from the 60's waiting for the moon colony they were promised. Lack of funding is also not an argument. What's next? The ISS is blown up in a false flag, and "sorry folks, it'll be at least another few decades." Meh. As long as the majority believes, the lies prevail. It's that simple. But it only lasts so long. When people wake up, we will either be free for the first time since our origin, or be totally destroyed. Which is more likely? There's a reason everything is dead around us.
Now, I could have left it there, but I'll open myself to even further criticism. What are the reasons for our failure?

1. We always destroy ourselves with technology before colonization.
2. The Earth periodically brings everything to near extinction. Often enough to prevent our escape. And we're overdue.
3. We get invaded by hostile aliens.
4. We are not allowed to leave the planet by either aliens or God? either for our own protection or something else's. Similar to keeping a dog in a yard.
5. We are in a simulation that doesn't have the vastness of space programmed, and our limit is our immediate surroundings. Answer to Fermi paradox.
6. There is no space, because we are in an enclosed environment as shown in common flat earth models. Which also answers the fermi paradox.
7. The Earth is SO HUGE. And we share it with multiple intelligence's that don't want us to know, for many reasons, perhaps disease exchange. So our portion of Earth is basically like North Sentinel Island. So they had to lie about the Model which confuses flat Earthers.

More, and maybe a mix of several. Either way. Which one helps you sleep better? It's picking your poison at this point.

Just to prepare for the very first manned mission to Mars, we should be launching resources there on sophisticated unmanned vehicles just as often as possible. Items such as fuel (liquid hydrogen & oxygen), spare parts, compressed dehydrated food, exploratory robots, batteries/nuclear generators, etc. could be sent on multiple long, slow orbits to be parked in orbit, or even waiting at the landing site waiting for the arrival of people in 2034-37.

As well, transmittion booster satellites could be seeded in long period, distantly-spaced orbits between Earth & Mars for efficiency & permanence of communication.

Having local data networks already established through micro-sized communication, GPS & weather tracking satellites in Ares stationary orbit above the landing site (as well as radio towers on the surface) would be needed for controlling the semi-autonomous AI robots used to develop the site. Other things that robots could set up before the first humans arrive:
• A power grid of nuclear systems isolated from the living quarters & cables.
• Robot manufacture & repairs station.
• Mining bots to locate, dig up & grind up any useable minerals in the vicinity of the landing site.
• Purification/cleaning systems to extract usable water from the toxic Martian saline ice, and useful minerals from Mars rocks.
• Building materials (just a few brick making robots - that use lasers to 3D print with Mars dust, or cast blocks of CO2 ice - could provide an important level of radiation protection for living / research quarters.
• AI controlled vehicle for exploratory missions & it''s garage.
• Storage for samples that cannot be allowed into habitats.

The more that can be assembled or manufactured on site, then the less that needs to be shipped the vast distance between our worlds - at staggering cost in time, money & resources. Yet, due to this mission being the most isolated that humans have ever been in human history & the shoe-string economics of space exploration, then the more redundancy that is build into everything, the better. Also, given the time constraints on the mission for them to synch up with Earth on their return trip, having much of the equipment for their exploration / experimentation assembled and waiting for their arrival makes sense - especially with the perspective of multiple further missions over the next 50 years..

~ ~ ~

NB: Just as with the Apollo lunar exploration missions, this 1st brief visit to Mars will be a suicide mission. If not instantly from one of the myriad terrible dangers of the mission, then (many years after they return) from repeated cancers caused by DNA damage from their prolonged exposure to solar radiation.

It takes utterly extraordinary people to do this kind of work, knowing that they may never return or will lose several decades of their lifespan - yet who would volunteer in an instant just for the opportunity to set foot on an Alien world...
By all means, let's spend all this money and effort on a project that will for sure pan out, it's not as if we're facing any challenges on earth at the moment

Wrong direction. The problem with Mars is that, because it doesn't have an ionosphere, it cannot be terraformed. You would either have to create an artificial ionosphere which would be extremely energy expensive (but technically possible) or create a series of habitat domes, which honestly would be better off under ground because they are going to need artificial lighting anyway.

A much better option would be Venus. Yes, this would actually be more difficult upfront than Mars, but Venus actually has more than one option. You can create cities in its sky where humans could where humans could live, and unlike Mars you can actually terraform its surface.

Venus doesn't have an ionosphere either, but it has a different reason for that. In the case of Mars, it used to have an ionosphere but when the core cooled down it ended. In the case of Venus, it has both a molten core and a molten surface. All you have to do to get the ionosphere going is to cool its surface which seems like a Monumental undertaking and it probably is, but at least that's possible to do which seems like a Monumental undertaking and it probably is, but at least that's possible to do.

The approach that I would take would be to intercept one of the many near-earth asteroids and as part of a long-term project outfit it with a series of thrusters in order to slightly alter its orbit around the sun. if you get the math right you can steer it into Venus. if you do this with more than one you can have one of them skim the atmosphere and another crash into the surface providing immediate Cooling. the seems sci-fi, but we have the technology to do this.

now, the stripped off atmosphere won't be significant enough and it will reabsorb most of its lost atmosphere over the course of a year. however, in this window of time there would be just enough time to see the planet with a genetically modified cyanobacteria give an extra tools to survive the higher temperatures. you might even throw in some halobacteria for good measure. the difference between them being that cyanobacteria share a common ancestor with the chloroplasts of plants and halobacteria had an alternative mechanism of photosynthesis that made use of retinol.

in any case, with photosynthesis taking place on Venus and the temperature is cooled down we should be able to terraform the surface within a few Generations tops.

You could instead try to terraform more slowly from within a cloud city, but the problem with this approach is that as the terraform continues your city will start to fall from the sky and given the number of generations it would take the odds of a future civilization willingly destroying their own civilization in order to make the surface of a planet Earth like is pretty low.

That all being said, I do think that underground Mars colonies are a good idea. Although we should probably start with lunar colonies.
