Couple of inaccuracies. Solar panels efficiency increases when they are cooled. Mars' avg temp is -63c, this offsets the lower amount of solar radiation that mars receives. Not the whole amount, but enough to make solar panels a viable possibility on mars. Secondly, just because of a lack of atmosphere does not mean that generating power from wind turbines is not feasable. Wind turbines would work in mars's atmosphere, albeit at a lower efficiency obviously, and they would work especially well during dust storms.

Kurzgesagt, you guys usually have top notch information and research, but you dropped the ball when you completely threw out the idea of solar and wind.

This Marsbase scenario relies on a lot of assumptions of progressing space technology. Tell me, how far along is our moonbase again....? Ah, right. There isn't one, and no current talks to develop one. I'm not saying we won't try to build either a martian or lunar base, just that this scenario requires a perfect storm of sorts, and it already takes years or sometimes decades just to get a simple rover or orbiter launched, let alone landed or passing by sites of interest. Even with private business interest building, I'm doubtful it will happen in the  next thirty to fifty years (and I hope I don't live past 80, egads... -_- ). So, likely  not in our lifetime.

Fun fact folks, the only place to land in the solar system (besides Earth) where you wouldn't have to worry about radiation is Callisto. Click bait nonsense. Perchlorates can be decontaminated by soaking the dirt in water. Likewise, filtering it out of the air isn't that difficult. Wind power actually works on Mars, because of the fact that the winds are generally higher than on earth, and there is geothermal power on Mars. There are also regions of elevated radioactivity that can be detected from orbit that denote concentrations of nuclear fuels. Nitrates can be added to the dirt using the same Haber-Borsch process as on earth in industrial farming, and with that done, the soil is ready to grow things. The bone demineralization and muscle loss in zeroG (as opposed to the more Clement Martian 3/8g) does not cause problems while in the reduced gravity environment; problems only occur on the return to earth. Stop apologizing for NASA's bureaucratic in efficiency by claiming the problem is harder than it is.

(Thanks for a new video! You are doing great and much needed job popularizing science!)

About the Mars base... you are right that it is a horrible idea, but it is very important for broadening our scientific horizons and having a better chance at unifying us as species (although Moon base should be a foremost priority for multiple reasons, mostly to significantly decrease the cost of the Mars missions and increase their payload).

The colonizers should expect this to be a one way mission. Also, one with likely a short life span due to harsh conditions. You have hinted this in your video, as well as the fact that there are plenty willing and qualified people who are ready to commit themselves to these conditions, so this is hardly an obstacle.

Energy wise, unless there is a drastic breakthrough that can compete with nuclear reactors they are the ONLY reliable source. Anything else at this point would be experimental and considered mostly for emergency situations. Nuclear fusion is relatively inexpensive, reactors can be sufficiently miniaturized to serve such remote outpost and made to be mostly fully automated. We can also send multiple reactors in advance of manned missions to wait for human arrival. They can be activated as needed, once the current reactor fuel supply has ran out (something tells me it would be easier to make them for a single use, for practicality and spent fuel utilization purposes).

Location of the base should obviously follow the water deposits, but to consider a base near polar caps is folly. Polar regions are significantly colder and would not allow for much of the surface exploration. Equator, on the other hand, may enjoy periodic shifts of temperatures above or near zero C', which would make surface missions much more feasible. I keep bringing up "surface mission" point, because the base itself and majority of the mission should be carried out below the surface. As you have mentioned as well, burying the base would offer protection against the elements and allow to build a much more robust outpost with greater flexibility and lesser risks at similar cost. While picking up the spot with natural caverns is reasonable, any custom tunnels for the base can be made in advance by robotic missions, controlled from Earth (yes, it will be much longer and likely more expensive than having humans on the ground, or in this case below it, we would save on building a temporary human habitat and risking lives). Humans are very fragile outside of our own environment, so we will need to go and stay deep (in hopes and as one of the primary goals to reach "geothermal", for a luck of better word, heat source), even though it means limited "outside window time", this is a necessity to insure a survival. If there are any reasonable hopes to terraform Mars there should be expansive subterranean presence in a first place.These tunnels can be expanded further by colonizers once initial bases are already established.

Fresh food - see the tunnels referenced above. The base/colony should be self-sufficient, with enough crew to overlap all required knowledge and skill multiple times, and in order to feed them a large system of underground farms will be required. Aside from conditioning the local soil to be useful, there is plenty of existing knowledge on how to create autonomous closed loop farms (e.g. "farm in a box") with high crop yield, and advancing fish farms to a "space" level can be achieved when needed. There is also dehydrated space food rations that can be used for emergency supplies and to add a variety to the diet, that can remain fresh for years, if not decades, and which should be sent in abundance to the future base site well in advance of any human missions.

And last and not least - 3D printing of everything that can be achieved with local materials, or recycled from those brought in by colonists. This is equally a crucial point, since bringing spare parts from Earth/Moon is not efficient and ability by the Mars base to manufacture them can be a matter of life and death. Existing 3D printing technologies should be perfected to suit requirements and source materials on Mars.

So, to summarize - Moon base first (even fairly basic one, comparing to the one planned at Mars), then lots of robotic and cargo supply missions at a chosen spot on Mars and then we can send several groups of brightest and bravest from around the globe, to stake a new ground in the name of Earth :)

The issue of Mars Dust is severely exaggerated. Yes, it's superfine dust laced with (mildly) toxic chemicals, but it is no match for a simple distilled-water shower to rinse off each spacesuit in the airlock. The dirty water can be re-distilled with minimal energy thanks to the low boiling point of water in such a thin atmosphere, and the dust can be mixed into concrete to ensure the same batch of dust never enters the airlock again. Over time enough dust would be trapped and concreted this way that the area surrounding the colony wouldn't need to constantly worry about dust intrusion anymore. The same thing would work on the Moon, if you're curious.

From what I understand terraforming an entire planet is never going to happen. Ever. Wish this would stop coming up as a plausible solution. We would essentially have to completely re-engineer nature, create plants that could survive under the conditions on mars and then somehow get them to make oxygen for us and/or be safe to eat (if we ever hoped to stop needing specialized growing rooms for our food), hope that we didn't inadvertently create species that would decimate other plant life we created or become hazardous to humans, and even then it would take tens of thousands of years if not millions for the entire planet to become anything close to resembling livable earth-like conditions with a thriving ecosystem. Mars is an experiment, a stepping stone to potentially finding and travelling to another habitable planet, it will never be earth 2.0 and the general public will be just as interested as moving to mars as they are moving to any other barely habitable desert climate region here on earth. All that said we should absolutely still push forward with our plans to set up colonies on mars. I just think people need to be realistic and stop pretending we have the intelligence or capability to redesign entire planets when we barely have a grasp on our own.

To colonize Mars

First- reduce launch costs to levels most civilians in developed countries can afford. Only governments and the richest can currently afford the launch costs of $3000 to $18,000 per kg. This cost must come down to something like $200 per kg. Space elevators, stratospheric\ mesospheric launch systems ( both balloon based and with special aircraft designed to carry a spaceship ), and reusable rockets all can reduce the cost of sending people and cargo into orbit, which is mandatory if Luna, Mars, etc are to be populated by civilians.

Second - make spaceships with faster propulsion methods. 6 to 9 months for a one way trip to Mars would expose people to too much radiation and microgravity. What's the point of sending people to Mars if they're laced with cancer and unable to walk when they land?

Third- perfect survival and self sufficiency. Martians will have to grow their own food, build and maintain their own pressurized and radiation protected housing and other buildings, make water potable, etc. For the basic first phase, it might be better to send robots to build the first habitat and make it liveable, complete with food and breathable air. The robots could also start the basic infrastructures a Mars village or town would need, mainly communication dishes and radio towers to more effectively stay in touch with Earth.

Fourth- other things. Once the basics are sussed out on Mars, it'll be time to think of ways to make the martians more comfortable. One consideration is entertainment. Part of the Martian village or town can be equipped with recreational facilities, at first, it will likely just be a hangout area with games, books, tablets, and maybe a TV. Later, bowling alleys, fitness centres, pools, artificial lakes, etc could be added. Another consideration is making more workspace and making it more comfortable. A comfortable martian is a happy martian.

Sadly, terraforming of Mars to make its surface habitable will never happen. Its iron core has long since cooled and hardened, stopping its rotation. Without rotation, it generates no magnetic field. No magnetic field means that solar radiation will rip away any substantial atmosphere and irradiate plant life. Unless we can melt a planet's core and get it spinning again, true life on Mars simply cannot exist.

Some small inaccuracies here. The pressure difference even in a total vacuum between the interior of a habitat pressurized to sea level would be 14.7 psi, or about as pressurized as a bicycle tire. This is not such a big difference that spherical and cylindrical hulls are an absolute necessity, as they are on submersibles and submarines which experience pressure differentials of many atmospheres.

This is how the cupola on the ISS is able to have large, flat windows without concern, and how the B.E.A.M. inflatable ISS module is possible. A hypothetical Mars habitat made of concrete, for example, could be rectilinear like buildings on Earth and still withstand the ~1 atm differential without much problem.

Windows are not necessarily a significant radiation hazard if they are convex out facing domes that poke through the shielding, you just wouldn't want to sit near them for hours on end. Radiation is directional like sunlight (in fact coming from the sun itself in this case) so shielding from the top is the most important. A handful of unshielded windows is not the end of the world.

Mars also has subsurface lava tubes accessible through "skylight" openings. If we can perfect the practice of sealing and pressurizing lava tubes here on Earth, making them accessible through an airlock fitted to the opening, we can then use this method to create much larger volumes of shirtsleeves habitat space on Mars than we could ever possibly afford to send by rocket in traditional "tin can" form.

"We set sail on this new sea because there is new knowledge to be gained, and new rights to be won, and they must be won and used for the progress of all people. For space science, like nuclear science and all technology, has no conscience of its own. Whether it will become a force for good or ill depends on man, and only if the United States occupies a position of pre-eminence can we help decide whether this new ocean will be a sea of peace or a new terrifying theater of war. I do not say that we should or will go unprotected against the hostile misuse of space any more than we go unprotected against the hostile use of land or sea, but I do say that space can be explored and mastered without feeding the fires of war, without repeating the mistakes that man has made in extending his writ around this globe of ours.

There is no strife, no prejudice, no national conflict in outer space as yet. Its hazards are hostile to us all. Its conquest deserves the best of all mankind, and its opportunity for peaceful cooperation may never come again. But why, some say, the Moon? Why choose this as our goal? And they may well ask, why climb the highest mountain? Why, 35 years ago, fly the Atlantic? Why does Rice play Texas?

We choose to go to the Moon! We choose to go to the Moon...We choose to go to the Moon in this decade and do the other things, not because they are easy, but because they are hard; because that goal will serve to organize and measure the best of our energies and skills, because that challenge is one that we are willing to accept, one we are unwilling to postpone, and one we intend to win, and the others, too."

- John F. Kennedy

They made a very elementary mistake concerning solar power. Sure, if you wanna put up solar arrays in the Sahara desert, then that's a lot more sunshine than at the best spots on Mars (the polar mountains). But if you look at solar radiation in Germany and then the Martian equatorial regions, you'll see they are entirely comparable. Mars does have some challenges, such as long-duration dust storms diffusing some of the light. A martian base is in any case expected to generate fuel for the return home, so any excess solar energy generates a little extra to burn during nights and dust storms. Another use of in-situ resources is to make more solar panels locally, rather than haul them all the way from Earth.

One problem with the "exploring space" thing is it ignores the reasons people explored in the past, wealth

In the past, exploring new uninhabited land was dangerous, but it was also lucrative, resources to exploit, land to claim, if you got their early and put in the work you'd be set for life


Granted, there is money to be made in space, but unlike the explorers of old, any wealth to be made by inhabiting other planets will not pay out within the lifetimes of the people who set up the settlement, or even the lifetimes of their children

The only people willing to do this would be the one's who are willing to do life threatening work with absolutely no reward, and such people do exist, but if we send them to mars (or any other planet) they will no longer be on Earth, which means most of the people currently working to better our species out of the goodness of their hearts and not at the behest of a corporation will be gone

A lot of technological innovation comes from the human desire for wealth, but that same desire for wealth also makes us unable to see more then a few years in the future, which isn't the best environment for true scientific advancement to thrive

A permanent off-world colony could become a beacon of hope and a step for humans to expand into the stars, a place where people can start anew and lead to a second scientific revolution, but it could just as easily become a folly that stunts scientific growth and leaves us even worse off as a society


My point is let's slow the f*** down and actually think about this, there is more support for a Mars base than there is for a Moon base, and is anyone actually considering Venus as an option?

I know Venus has the whole "crushing atmosphere and melting lead" thing going on, and of course shipping things off of Mars would be easier and cheaper, but it does have a lot of tangible advantages over Mars (the biggest of which is a comparable gravitational pull)

If we're going to do this, we need to do it right, and part of that is to actually consider all of our options instead of just doing the thing that sounds the coolest

Being in the caves also has the added benefits of having large deposits of ore in the cave system like ( iron, uranium, gold silver, and anything that is produced deep in a planets core.) The elements are in the cave system because lava is produced deep within a planet then they are brought up by geological activity like volcanoes and lava caves to which they are deposited in. If you want to know more about how people would survive in these caves or on mars in general then I suggest that you watch the natural geographic series named "Mars".

Great work, very detailed summary of the challenges and requirements for a Mars base. I would like to point out that one of the reasons to go to Mars is to be able to produce fuel (methane or even hydrogen) so as to be able to get further out in the solar system. Since Mars has only 1/3 the gravity, 1/2 the radius, and 1/10th the mass, the energy required to escape Mars' orbit is significantly less than Earth. Thus, a rocket of the same size would be able to fly much farther leaving Mars instead of Earth, potentially enabling us to reach the gas giants, their moons, and other celestial bodies.

This is the one big thing I disagree with Elon Musk about. Mars would be great to visit, but terrible for a sizable colony. Venus is by far the superior expansion option in the short term. Better gravity, stronger solar power, and no fine dust issue. Radiation is still a problem, but floating cloud cities would have some measure of mobility, and thus be able to hide from intense solar storms if they hug the terminator. The problem is that building a city with no solid ground under it is a really alien concept for a lot of people, and much harder to popularize.

Long term, it's just better and much cheaper to start building O'Neill cylinders where we can control every variable. No amount of terraforming is going to fix the gravity or magnetosphere on Mars.

Just deconstruct the asteroid belt and turn it into billions of O'Neill cyllinders. You get earth-normal gravity, whatever kind of terrain you want, breathable atmosphere, and you can shelter it from radiation by nesting it in a stationary cylinder and covering that with the useless regolith churned out by your asteroid mining operation.
Sending machines to Mars instead of humans is a much better idea.

The order we should colonize in:
#1. Earth (Arctic, Deserts, Undersea)
#2. Earth's gravitational field (the ISS, rotating habitats, experimental labs, giant solar panels in space)
#3. The Moon (Underground bases, mining fields, material resource extraction, automated factories, basic colonies)
#4. Venus (Floating cities, gas resource harvesters, advanced colonies, basic tourism)
#5. Mars (Resource harvesting, trade with other planets, underground bases, tourism)
(This is where humanity really becomes interplanetary and a space-faring civilization safe from destruction)
#6. The Asteroid Belt (Ceres, Vesta, Pallas, where will do mining, ice harvesting, living in smaller space habitats and giant space stations)
#7. Interplanetary Space (massive solar collectors, space habitats, space stations)
#8. Outer planets (Neptune, Saturn, Jupiter, where we will do more resource collection and use these planets as gateways to other planets)
#9. The sun (Dyson Swarm, starlifiting, serious energy and mineral extraction)
#10. Alpha Centauri

I know a fair bit about space and colonization, and I think this is the correct order. Each stage allows us to get better at colonizing the next stage. Colonizing the Arctic can help us to learn about constructing and maintaining distant human habitats in freezing conditions. So, colonizing Mars is still pretty far off. Reaching that stage will definitely be worthwhile, however.

We have work to do.

It's clear that setting up intermediate outposts would be a better alternative.

We should start with the moon, and do something similar there first, use it to create our first facilities in space that would allow to transport around much larger quantities of materials and even manufacture finished products directly from space resources.
Maybe set up automated stations between Earth and Mars to refill spaceships fuel tanks and make communication between outer outposts more reliable. Maybe these could also be used to relay energy via masers, we could launch swarms of satellites with big solar panels in smaller orbits and then send the energy back to where it's needed, so we can do without using nuclear power.

Having a solid presence in space can also allow for the creation of superstructures in space that wouldn't be possible otherwise, like big spaceships or space stations, at least that is if we can harvest and manufacture off-world. This can make the problem of radiations trivial, as we could easily build vessels with thick enough bulkheads and hulls, and could simplify the logistics of Mars colonization a lot, as we could simply put a space station in orbit, where people would reside, and only send robots to the surface to terraform. Astronauts would only be there to do research and check everything works fine, and to do an occasional trip down if something's wrong.

2 minutes in and the first fault is found. Wind power on Mars is roughly twice more effective than on Earth.
Generating power through fissile nuclear reactions, aka heating something up a liquid with radioactive beta decay, is a lot easier on Mars.
Living underground is actually feasible. Only the surface of mars is made up of perchlorates. Mars is also rich in Feldspar.
The Soil of Mars could be electrolytically turned into Chlorine Salts and Oxygen gas, meaning that there is no lack of oxygen on Mars, Although hydroponics and aeroponics will be the main methods to grow food, and seeing as you only need electricity and water, and a few minerals namely iron, sulfur, nitrogen, phosphor and carbon for growing plants, it's not really that hard to grow anything, anyways.

The poison and harsh conditions that he refers to; well, there is life that thrives in those conditions on this planet. Such life would make short work of perchlorates. Over 40 phylogenetically and metabolically diverse microorganisms capable of growth via perchlorate reduction have been isolated since 1996. Most originate from the Proteobacteria but others include the Firmicutes, Moorella perchloratireducens and Sporomusa sp., and the archaeon Archaeoglobus fulgidus. With the exception of A. fulgidus, all known microbes that grow via perchlorate reduction utilize the enzymes perchlorate reductase and chlorite dismutase, which collectively take perchlorate to innocuous chloride. In the process, free oxygen (O2) is generated.

One interesting idea would be to build the habitat under water (I've not seen this discussed).  10m of water is equal to 1 atmosphere, and provides significant additional radiation shielding, particularly for neutrons.  If you don't like the idea of being under water, then you could build the habitat under a water storage area.  That would give the shielding, but not the pressure advantage.  Having lots of liquid water around would also be a great idea, since you have thirsty astronauts and plants.

Regarding nuclear fuel, Mars HAS nuclear fuel, but not in the form we are used to with current reactors.  Mars soil and the moon has significant thorium in it.  A working breeder reactor with highly enriched fuel would be more than enough to get things started, as neutrons are needed to convert thorium into U233 which then provides further energy (known as a breeder reactor).  Endless fuel shipments should not be required once the reactor is set up and thorium is obtained from the soil.

All that said, I would still go if given the opportunity. Expanding to a multi-planetary presence is vital for the future survival of the human race, and options in the Solar system are pretty thin on the ground. The only advantage Earth's moon holds for us is proximity, we can get to and from it relatively quickly. Mercury is out because most of our technology would just burn up. Venus is out because of the insanely corrosive and high pressure atmosphere. Unless there's some compelling wealth of resources there that would make life easier, I don't see us ever colonising Venus. The gas giants have a couple of interesting moons, such as Titan and Europa, but they are much harder to reliably get to. If a two year wait for colony support is too long to be useful, then that puts everything beyond Mars off the table, too.

Despite its challenges, and inhospitable nature, we have to make the best we can of Mars, at least until scientists discover magic, and can get us to other stars faster than light. We can't just hold out hope that we'll be able to drop a hundred colonists on a lush and fertile world like our forebears did in colonising America, and Australia.

all but a few of the points made in this video have already been solved from the radiation issue (we have an ISS and it faces a larger radiation issue, but it's been solved for a long time using shielding, it has windows as well, so covering the shelter with the soil and ice is just pointless and a waste of time and resources) to the power (solar energy would work and when wind can be gathered during the dust storms, mars is easier than this video makes it out to be and if you include the fact that we've already made the required tech with the ISS (why did he even mention the pressure issue, that's been solved from when we began going to space). The dust issue was WAY WORSE on the moon, but the dust on mars isn't as bad as on the moon and they've already built specialized suits that never enter the habitat (which has also already been built by the way) specifically to deal with the dust. The soil itself is does need some nutrients, but so does our own soil and the chemical he says mars' soil lacks, is the same chemical that our own often lacks and is why we have fertilizer (the alkaline is a real issue however). The water can be gathered from underground (the water often seeps to the surface as discovered by our rovers). The muscle and bone degradation isn't that bad of a problem either when you once again consider the ISS, and same for the psychological bit (it's as if he forgot that the ISS exists)

I still think all this colonisation is a stupid idea. Humans evolved for living on Earth. If some people are to settle on Mars indefinitely, in the long run they might evolve to survive Mars, but we're talking thousands of years, there's no guarantee that they're going to survive that long there. I would not be surprised at all if a large amount of babies born on mars would be degenerated. All in all, chances of reasonable way of living on Mars are slim. Even if a meteor'd hit earth, likely Earth would still be way more habitable than Mars. Human biology is not prepared for space, because it had no reason to evolve for that and our technology, as amazing as it is, is still nowhere near good enough to bring earth-like conditions to other places in the universe. The only other option would be genetical engineering (and we're still far away from that). All in all it's a bad idea and waste of money, trying to build human colonies on Mars. There are some technologies that if developed for the mission to Mars, could be useful for Earth, but why not just fund those because they're useful for Earth? I don't see why we are colonising Mars instead of Venus. Many of you think that Venus is a hell scape with temperatures higher than melting point of lead, and you are right. However Venus also has an atmosphere 90 times denser than Earth's, which means that we can EASILY make habitats float there. Breathable air filled airships would float somewhere between 50-60 Km. And at these heights, specifically 55 Km, Venus is VERY much habitable.


1:05 "Cold" - Mars is extremely cold at nights and warm during days. Temperature usually goes between -90 C to +20 C. That is a 110 C temperature difference day and night, which would harm equipment. A Venus colony floating at 55 km would be at a comfortable 27 C degrees. And Venus doesnt have any temperature difference between day and night and it doesn't have seasons too.



1:50 "Mars is Very Energy Poor" - Venus is much closer to Sun which means you can harvest solar power effectively there, on top of that its dense atmosphere allows the harvest of wind power.


2:35 "Mars's atmosphere is 1% as dense as Earth's" - While floating at 55 km Venus' atmosphere is roughly at the same density as easths. So you won't have to worry about your habitats exploding. While going outside for maintenance, the astronauts can just wear thin clothes that will protect them from scarce amounts of acid found in the air. They won't have to wear massive suits that will keep them pressurized. Remember the movie Martian? In the movie a small leak causes a whole part of the station to blow up.


3:03 "Mars has deadly radiation" - Venus' thick atmosphere protects humans from solar radiation, on top of that Venus has a induced magnetosphere that further blocks radiation.


4:58 "Martian poles has water" - It is true that water is easier to come by at Mars, but that would mean your colony has to be near the poles, which barely gets any sunlight. So any hopes you had left for solar power is gone. Venus' atmosphere has trace amounts of water vapour, which can be filtered. It will be slow, but colonies can recycle water so that there will be minimal loss of water.


5:40 "Mars barely has any gravity" - This is the most serious issue about Mars. We have barely any control over our biology. And our biology doesn't allow humans to live in low gravity environments for long. Some scientist believe that babies can't develop correctly in low gravity, which means a truly self sustaining colony, a colony where people can live and populate is impossible on Mars. Venus's gravity is roughly same as Earth's so none of these problems exist on Venus.


6:55 "Narrow travel windows" - You can travel to Venus every 584 days, while for mars you have to wait for 780 days. On top of this, traveling to Venus takes shorter and requires less fuel.

Cleaning the Martian soil of perchlorates could be accomplished by synthetic biology. First, we could genetically engineer Dechloromonas Aromatica to metabolize perchlorates more quickly (which is something we want to do here on Earth anyway, to keep our water sources clean). We could then evolve a unique strain of the microbes in increasingly Mars-like simulated environments, since the genetic modifications necessary would likely be too complicated to engineer directly. This strain could then be seeded across Mars in specific areas where we plan to colonize.

After watching a video, I think I have some things to point out.
About creating semi-permanent outpost:
Obviously we need to send robots first, so they can build the base with all things needed for humans habitat. Humans are too fragile for that mission and too much resources and time will be wasted.
Agree with a Moon base, before Mars base & colonization. Without Moon base first, it will be very hard to work on Mars.
There is a great discussion which way to regenerate Mars magnetosphere is the best. So lets see if there is a right way for that first.
For shielding a base. there is already solution, same as it is on the Moon - create a base underground, in a cave or a crater. No need to cover a base on a surface with a dirt - to much time and energy consuming.
Space-suits never enter a base - already that was on the Moon missions, if you see videos how astronauts got out from the Moon rovers.
For water, there is no need to settle base near Martian poles - it's enough to deliver water from there through tubes.
Why not build rotating living spaces in a first place, before sending humans on Mars?
So, overall we need Moon base first and lots of robots & equipment before even thinking to send humans. Also: Dyson sphere around the Sun and factory-base on Mercury is awesome idea.

Of course, if we’re already sending up nuclear power sources, we may as well send them aboard atomic rockets, powered by nuclear technologies. Even the pessimal case, with the rockets only being a little better than current chemical thrusters and ion drives, this can widen the launch windows for hohmann orbits and increase the mass budget per launch. Best case scenario, you might even get a “torch ship” out of atomic rocketry, which could allow transit to Mars no matter where Earth and Mars are in their orbits inside of two weeks.

As for dry Martian dust, laden with perchlorate salts, could airlocks be fitted with water to wet the dust and clean down the suits? This might make airlocks unnecessarily complicated, though.

I'm more optimistic of artificial space habitats myself, but I think we'll figure it out. We REALLY need to make sure we set our explorers and settlers up for success first though. Send automated shipments of supplies FAR in excess of what they will need, for any reasonable contingency. Deaths on Mars will be potentially devastating to the future of many Mars exploration/settlment programs. I hope that we will instead honor those martyrs to humanity's spacefaring future, and redouble our efforts.

We can definitely pull it off though. I look forwards to all the fast approaching advances in science that will get us there, to the moon again, and to the asteroid belt. The future we have collectively dreamed of for nearly a century is almost here.

Here's an idea... - An orbiting (rotating for gravity as strong as Earth-norm) farms to produce food, air, water-reclamation and be a possible life-boat. - If it's large enough the crews on the Mars surface can be rotated out every couple of months. This station can be one of a fleet, and after a few years, it can be piloted home when a 2nd one arrives to replace it. - The used one can undergo maintenance, replenish growing soil and upgrades and sent to it's next task. Windmills are feasible on Mars they just have to be designed different, also the lower gravity, almost zero seismic activity and thin air allow for much bigger constructions and easier construction, also nuclear power should be more efficient with a higher temperature and pressure gradient and you can build pretty much where you want, unlike on Earth and you don't have to worry as much about safety.
Also living underground is easier on Mars with essentially zero ground water, again no seismic activity and lower gravity, you can dig where you like and stable cave structures including giant caves can be found on Mars these caves could be reasonably easy to live in with limited radiation huge amount of space where you could move about in a relatively unrestricting pressure suit, you might even be able to fully or partially pressurize a large part of a cave and grow large plants and trees under grow lambs and/or transported concentrated sunlight.
I think the biggest problems would me mining and transporting H20 and metals etc as they aren't usually concentrated or as close to the surface as Earth.

Well animated, but backwards and utterly wrong. The sensible approach would be the settle one or both martian moons first, where you can just duplicate the lunar facilities, and build centrifuges with much greater ease, and then start sending material down from there on a constant basis. It's also completely wrong to say we'll be using nuclear power AND we'll only have launch windows every two years. If we're using nuclear reactors on the ground, we'll almost certainly have nuclear engines for planet-planet transfer, and that gives us a lot more options. Finally the moon is pretty comparible to Mars, so if we have an established base there, we've done all this stuff before, and a second time will be easier.

Indeed this will be the most strenuous and rudimentary project humans have ever done. However, with a proper mindset and analytical disposition, I can definitely agree with Kurzgesagt that colonizing Mars is probable. The calcium perchlorates near the Curiosity landing will be an especially complicated task in terms of isolating it from the colonization pods. However, through my own research in a biochemistry lab, I do think that it is possible for methanogens and haloarchaea to enumerate under similar conditions. As a high school student, I currently examining how these microorganisms utilize ClO4 in their metabolic pathways and then trying to genetically engineer them via site-directed mutagenesis to make them tolerant to the conditions on Mars. After this experimental process, I will then try to construct photovoltaic cells using the rhodopsin proteins found in specific haloarcaea (they act as optical light-harvesters) by immobilizing them into Au anodes. Despite the lack of solar UV emittance from the sun on Mars as well as dust storms, this method could significantly improve the quantum efficiency of the solar cells and hopefully lengthen the time of solar energy utilization on Mars (with the alternative usage of nuclear energy). I really enjoyed this video and I hope it inspires others to take on these sorts of challenges and turn on their innovative mindsets!

While I wholly and truly find the idea of extraterrestrial colonisation awesome, I also hope that we are “ethically and morally mature” for such an undertaking.

What I mean by this is that I don’t think we should end up expanding because we have made our Earth uninhabitable. Undoubtably such would be a driver for expansion, but viewed through this lens I think expansion ultimately would be a crutch to our inability to live in a sustainable relationship with a planet; it would give us an easy way out of a do-or-die predicament, surely, but to simply continue unsustainable living on another planet would be through and through morally indefensible to me. In such a scenario, I would probably see the human race as effectively no more than parasites.
I have a dreadful fantasy of the human race in which we, much like the Tyranids of Warhammer 40K, roam from world to world, stripping them from all of their resources, mineral and biological, only to leave a dead husk behind and march ever onwards in a quest to consume. The crucial difference between the Tyranids and us in this scenario is, to me, that these fictional aliens are slaves to their own instincts of relentless consumption, as I’ve understood it, and that we aren’t so, at least entirely. As a conscious and reflexive species, I believe that we are ethically and morally obliged to move towards sustainability and harmony with our environment.

Now, this may all be a bit too gloomy and pessimistic, for we have surely developed many technologies and insights which should give us a far more ideal starting-point for extraterrestrial colonisation in terms of sustainablity. I just hope, almost pray to some God, that we will make, what I consider to be, the ethical and moral choice to prioritise a vision of long-term ecological harmony over short-term consumerist profiteering, for the latter can surely seem alluring in a supposedly infinite universe.

1. The dust is a problem because of the lack of water. Put some water in the atmosphere and the dust will rain out.

2. Lava tubes are an obvious place to live that is sufficiently shielded.

3. Venus and Mars are a natural complement for terraforming: A parasol at Venus' L1 point will cool it down and cause solid CO2 to sublime out. After building an orbital ring around each planet you can have dry ice scooped up by robots from Venus and sent to Mars via their orbital rings. Similarly the excess N2 (Venus has several times what is needed for an Earthlike atmosphere) can be frozen and sent from Venus to Mars.

4. Alternatively, N2 could be sent from Titan.

5. Water ice is abundant in the outer solar system and can be put on a zero-fuel, slow trajectory to Mars using flybys and Lagrange points.

6. Keeping volatiles such as CO2 and N2 frozen solid is simply a matter of shielding them from the Sun (with a thin, shiny surface kept stationed between the cargo and the Sun) and exposing them to space (temp ~ a few degrees K).

7. Venus does not need to be cooled all the way down to Earth normal to start being useful: The first places to achieve Earth normal pressure and temperature will be mountain tops where orbital ring tethers and bases can be situated. Then as they in turn get down to arctic temperatures the bases can be moved downhill to Earth-normal temp and pressure zones and robots can start mining dry ice from the places further uphill.

Glad I stumbled across this so I know what the chickens are planning.

* Solar power probably is enough. Elon Musk plans to land enough solar power to bring back a BFR with just a few non-returnable BFR. The power to create that fuel is a lot more than you need to run basic life support. Even in severe dust storms solar cells will still produce a moderate fraction of their usual power. This means that a solar power array sufficient to generate return fuel will be able to provide plenty of power to just keep the crew alive in the event of a prolonged dust storm. There won't even be unexpected delays in the return flight so long as there is a BFR-full of fuel stockpiled.

*Windows will still be fine because radiation coming in at steep angles will pass through much more atmosphere, even on mars. I think cylinder shaped towers with a water supply above would provide very good viewing area and good shielding.. Also, a lot of the estimates of radiation damage are based on a linear assumption. There is some evidence suggesting this may significantly overestimate the probability of cancers from continual low level radiation.

Amazing video as always! And I love the animations! However, why could they not employ lead lined glass (or acrylic) as is used in nuclear storage facilities, medical rediological imaging, those large full body security scanners, etc, to provide windows? It shouldn't really be a weight issue if they're launching from the moon. Additionally having moon launched missions means that some thicker shielding for the bases wouldn't be too hard to send, either already integrated into the structure or as a sort of cladding that gets attached on during deployment (keep in mind that it's unlikely that a mars base would be deployed in the way depicted, but rather it would likely arrive in parts or partially disassembled on a larger more durable ship). The dust is definitely a major issue though, as currently our solution to dust problems on mine sites and such is to spray it down with water, which isn't exactly a viable strategy there. Finally, I'm not sure what type of nuclear reactor you assumed they would use, but refueling every few years sounds like it's of the old solid state fuel uranium fission reactors we use now, which would really suck tbh. I think it's more likely that they'd use either an array of RTGs or possibly a molten salt reactor as these are much more fuel efficient nuclear energy sources (and safer in many regards). Anyway, keep up the awesome work, you guys rock!

Would be great if you made an episode about "self sufficient space habitats". We are so driven by settling other planets, which of course I think we should do, that we forget that space habitats might be a more economical and also healthier first step into space. For instance, space habitats might be cheaper as we can start building them incrementally, piece-by-piece. As we did with the ISS, we can lego-build it. Another important aspect might be health: with space habitats we can decide how much gravity we want. There are cheaper techniques where we could wire up an initial station to a wire, and put a weight (or another small station) at the other end, have them spin around to reproduce gravity. Then we can move these pieces closer to asteroid belts to get resources. A planet on the other hand is a gravity-well: it will always cost us energy and money to get out of such wells. Why not shift the attention to the more natural first step of colonizing space which in my opinion are space habitats?

Why have a moon base as a hub? It takes more Delta V and more time in sitting around outside a magnetosphere to rendevous and do whatever at the moon, compared to just taking a 3-4 month direct trip to mars, aerobraking on the atmosphere, and landing. What could a moon base even supply something like Starship (formerly BFR) with? Not fuel, not supplies, not anything meaningful. 100 tons to orbit, in-orbit refueling, and a pressurized volume greater than the ISS; only ships like Starship will even be making the trip to Mars.

Don't kid yourself about NASA's SLS or any derivative one-off architectures. It'll be modular, very compatible, mass-produced habitat modules, not unique ISS-inspired modules.

There are many factual problems with this video:
* there is no need for a Moon base before Mars base. In fact it is counter-productive. It takes just as much energy to go from Earth to surface of the Moon as to the surface of Mars. This is because Mars has some atmosphere and you can use it for aerobraking, while on the Moon all the breaking must be done by rockets only - super expensive
* there is no point in making habitats on surface of Mars due to radiation and temperature, so even first habitats will be underground with a few above-ground modules for sightseeing and transfer to surface. CO2 ice will just evaporate during the day. 2-3 meters of Mars ground easily reduces radiation down to the same as on Earth. Surface exposure for a few hours a day is negligible, unless there is a solar storm
* pressure is not a big problem, especially if habitats are pressurized to less that 1 atm. Tires on earth easily maintain several atm of pressure with tiny rubber walls and gas storage tanks can hold tens of atm of pressure easily
* solar power is going to be primary on Mars because it is much easier to send a 100 tons of solar panels and few inverters to Mars than invent a new nuclear reactor that will be able to work without maintenance there for years - we do not have such nuclear technology at the moment. Also do not discount wind - despite pressure being low, the wind speeds sometimes compensate for that and with proper design wind power could be competitive with solar and will at least easily cover the deficit during dust storms. Or we can just stop the methane conversion factory for the duration of the storm
* there is plenty of water deposits almost everywhere on Mars just a few meters deep, there are craters that are literally filled with water ice. this allows settling further away from poles and nearer more interesting mineral deposits and more optimal landing sites
* perchlorates are easily washable with water
* research so far seems to suggest that even lunar gravity is sufficient to make bodies work fine, it is microgravity (like almost zero) like on ISS causes big problems over long term

So many of these problems are exaggerated in this video.

 First, you don't build your base in direct sunlight. Mars is covered with canyons and mountains that can easily protect you from the radiation associated with direct sunlight. As for your greenhouses, use plastics we've already developed on Earth that screen out the harmful wavelengths and use strands resistant to radiation.

Second, you would not need "constant supplies from Earth". This isn't the 1960's, we have 3-D printers that can take raw materials and create almost anything we need on Mars. New designs can be developed on Earth and simply uploaded to our colonists.

Third, while nuclear is the most reliable energy option, solar energy is quite plentiful on Mars. Though it does receive 40% of the sunlight Earth does, it also has a MUCH thinner atmosphere meaning more of the available sunlight actually reaches the surface. Dust storms obscure the surface for sometimes months on end, but enough batteries could compensate for that. Automation could produce literally endless solar panels providing all the energy our colonists need. Also, geothermal has hardly been ruled out as a viable energy source as the core of Mars is estimated to be 1230 C or 2246 F. While probably not enough to power a robust industry, it is certainly enough to heat our colonists through the cold Martian night.

Finally, perchlorate salts can LITERALLY be washed deep into the ground with water. Nitrogen can LITERALLY be pulled out of the air for crops. I get that you guys are trying to make an interesting video that draws a lot of attention, but please keep the sensationalism to a minimum. Colonizing Mars will indeed be hard, but we've faced bigger challenges as a species and doing this is not nearly as risky as it's made out to be.

All in all, most of the points raised in this video are valid, but this one deserves a more optimistic take!

Hey, it's me again (you don't know me but it's fine). I was writing this to a certain guy on Youtube I used to watch, thought I'd share it with you too.
I used to work on a farm (and I still am) without any access to PC or a laptop, the only things I had were my old cell phone and my tablet. So I thought to myself "Well, I can at least write something on the Internet." Thus, I began to start translating some books and stuff (there was a time when I used to make subtitles to the anime and TV shows). Wanna hear how many people have read it? 15.. On a fully fledged book I spent a whole month translating.
Depression took me over. I couldn't do anything for at least couple of months. Then, while surfing the net, I found these cool free books called Programming Intro, volumes 1 to 3. I didn't know anything about the author, but when I did I was shocked. It was a professor of one of the most prestigious universities in my country, and he was putting up his books _for free_! It's unbelievable!
I began studying from the basics. How PC works, CPU, RAM, Linux... Then it went to Free Pascal, assembler, ANSI C, how the net works, a bit of C++... Then 2019 took over. I was finally enjoying something. So many ideas were boiling in my head, I even wrote some lyrics to the future songs (wanna hear some? I could share with you on Twitter), took a month off and went back to my hometown.
When I got back, I knew exactly what to do. Spent some money on RPG Maker, saarched for some pixel art tutorials and then... I realized I couldn't do it. Never in my life I had thought I needed to draw something. It was too hard for me. Words like "anti-aliasing" sent me shivers down my spine. But I was still determined to make it. I took some all nighters, made the skeleton of my story, wrote down all the dialogues and jokes. I was basically ready.
Somewhere in the middle of making my game I got sick, my throat still hurts a bit, and what's more funny is that they're saying it's gonna be up to -45 C next week (when I neet to go to a dentist). I still kept going no matter what. Finally I was done. It was only a week but it felt like eternity. My old laptop was freezing like crazy (which isn't surprising, considering I haven't upgraded it in 7 years). What's more funny is that I couldn't even run my game properly (I guess my rocking 256 MB graphics card can't afford it), so it felt like a living hell beta testing it. I made an account on itchio, added some screenshots and published it. One person even downloaded it on the very first day and... that's it. No matter how many times I was begging in the youtube comments or on reddit no one was willing to play it.
And now I'm writing this to you. I don't even know why I'm doing this. Maybe to share my experience or to relieve my burden just a little bit. It doen't matter now. I'm gonna move out again in weeks and I don't even know when I'm gonna be back. Why did I even bother making it funny or interesting... I don't even like memes. Sorry for taking your time in case you're reading this, and go have a wonderful life. You deserve it.

So, to start I need to explain where I come from. I was raised as a round-earther from a young age. Since my first year in school as a five year old, I was taught by my teachers that the Earth is round. That the Earth revolves around the Sun. That this is the reason for day and night. Brainwashed. Today I am going to dispel belief in those theories once and for all. I would like to emphasize my word choice of “theory,” because that is exactly what they are. Nobody that is reading this page has ever been to space. Nobody has seen evidence of any of these theories first hand. Why do we choose to believe the government on these matters – the same government that has lied so many times and in so many ways to us. This is the same government that just so happened to neglect to tell its people about the heinous atrocities committed in Vietnam. I want you, as readers, to view misinformation from the government with a cynical eye, doubting everything and anything you are told. So, enough about me. You are here to see my proof that the Earth is flat. I am going to start with the basics of the belief. First, we will start with the widely recognized premise that the universe was created in a massive explosion of highly compressed matter.  This explosion sent matter flying outwards at a rate of acceleration of exactly 9.81 meters per second squared. Now, how does this explain flat earth? Imagine a boat sail, pushed by the wind. Does the boat sail suddenly form a ball shape when blown on by the wind? No. It does bend slightly, but this is because of uneven pressure caused by the boat going slower than the wind that propels it. In the frictionless vacuum of space, it wouldn’t bend at all. So, what would make one think that matter would suddenly and randomly form a perfect sphere? It simply makes no sense at all. Another thing that needs to be established is that there is no such thing as gravity. The feeling of so-called “gravity” is in fact the Earth accelerating constantly away from the center of the universe. This is similar to when you push on the gas pedal of your car and are pushed back in your seat. It is the same, familiar, principle of inertia on a macro scale. So, now to address the issue of day and night, as well as the moon in the flat Earth view. The first thing I would like to point out is that the sun is like a giant light bulb powered by ludicrous amounts of static electricity. It is a huge flat piece of tungsten that, as it moves through space (I will explain this later) rubs against the other particles and collects static electricity. There is enough static electricity continuously building up to “power” the sun. One of the main arguments against this ideology is that the sun appears round to us. The answer is simple. Lightbulbs glow because of resistance built up by the tungsten filament. If you look closely at a incandescent light bulb, you will see that the area of greatest compounded resistance is at the center of the filament, where it is the brightest. The same principle applies to the sun. The spot of greatest resistance is the center, and it gets lower and lower as you move outwards, forming a circle of even radius that glows, hence the circular appearance. Now, how does this explain day and night? The sun was formed at the beginning of the universe just a split second sooner than the Earth, which means that it is further from the epicenter of the explosion. The Earth was formed immediately after the sun and directly between it and the  explosion force. The Earth shielded the sun from the continued push of the great explosion, and the sun continued to move at the same speed while the Earth accelerated towards it. It seemed like a collision was imminent. Luckily, though, the moon was formed behind the Earth and a little offset to the side. Now, as we all probably know, electricity of any kind moving through any material causes electromagnetic fields. The sun, with massive amounts of electricity moving through it, produces an equally as massive electromagnetic field. We also know that as easily as electromagnetism can pull something towards it, it can push something of the same charge away from itself. The moon is made of the naturally occurring mineral lodestone, which can be naturally magnetically charged. The moon’s charge was opposite that of the sun’s electromagnetic field. This caused the sun to push itself away from the moon and thus avoid the collision with the Earth. The sun would have sailed off into space, but the earth contains neutral ferromagnetic materials that caused the sun to be attracted to it. This caused the moon to stay close to the Earth as well. So, what happened next is what causes day and night, and the appearance of sunset and sunrise. The sun moved to the side of Earth and the Earth quickly accelerated past. The sun, now no longer shielded from the blast, got a boost of energy and accelerated upwards again, catching up with the Earth. Its “fall” from in front of the Earth gave it momentum that was then turned around, allowing it to accelerate faster than the Earth. Keep in mind that during this whole time, the sideways momentum of the sun caused by its disattraction to the moon is continuing. Once the sun passes the Earth, it again passes into its shadow and is no longer effected by the power of the blast. The Earth accelerates towards it, the moon pushes it to the side in a circle, always keeping the moon directly opposite of the position of the sun, and the cycle starts all over again, creating day and night. It is worth noting that the moon is made of a flat sheet of lodestone, and the circular appearance is caused by the circular beam of light let off by the sun. This is a similar effect to shining a circular spotlight on a flat wall. It makes a circle, not the rectangular shape of the wall. So now I have explained the basic mechanics of Flat Earth, but why would the government want to hide this from us? It is all based on crude oil. If you remember, back in the medieval times it was widely known that the Earth was flat. This is also the time when all machines were very simple and primitive. They did not use oil. The first machine to use oil was the simple steam engine. It used oil as a lubricant to ensure smooth operation of the pistons. The first steam engine is thought to have been invented in ancient Egypt, before the year 30 B.C. It was in practice a failure, but in principle it lived on. The technology seemed to stagnate for almost 1700 years until the first commercial steam engine was debuted in Europe in 1698. This is not to say, however, that the steam engine wasn’t used between 30 B.C. and 1968 A.D. It was likely used in secret by European powers who, not wanting to reveal their advantage to rival countries, did not document its use. They likely would have quickly realized that as steam technology grew, so would the need for oil. Africa was already being looted for rubber necessary for war machines, and they realized that this would soon be the case for oil. Explorations by men such as Magellan and Columbus, were to find crude oil reserves, not just for the sake of sailing around the world Magellan quickly found that there were massive oil reserves in the ice caps that rim the flat Earth. (These ice caps make up Antarctica and the North Pole and circle all around the perimeter of the Earth, forming a massive ice wall. This ice wall does form a circle shape because of the concentration and qualities of the way heat spreads, so in that way the reachable Earth is a circle in shape) Countries knew that knowledge of this fact would make them rich and powerful, and did everything they could to keep it from others. Thus they invented the myth of the Earth being round. It is all a ploy to keep power in the hands of the governments in an age of oil dependency. The best way to keep people from finding out about massive oil reserves on the edge of the Earth is to make them not even believe in the edge of the Earth. This sham is kept up today, and will likely be kept up as long as possible by the governments, because to admit that they were lying for all this time would be a massive loss of face. Do you remember the Antarctic treaty signed by the 12 most powerful countries in the world in 1959? This wasn’t just some inconsequential treaty about a barren plain of ice, but rather the most important economic agreement in the history of civilization. Want to go to the continent of Antarctica or the North Pole? You’ll need a very hard-to-obtain permit for that. All because of the enormous greed of the leaders of our world. Actually, there is a very concrete solution to the radiation problem that NASA is already working on : the Mars L1 project.

See, there are these things called Lagrange points : between two celestial bodies in an orbital relationship, in this case Mars and the Sun, there are several points in space positionned in a straight line between the two where each aster's gravity reaches a wierd equilibrium, and if an object of neglectful mass (compared to the two) sits in one of these, it will STAY in prefect alignment to the sun and mars, even as mars moves around.

So NASA went : "Hey, if we put a big ass magnet in one of these, that'll create a magnetic shield that will divert the solar winds and protect mars". And that's how, in 2018 (if i remember correctly), we already designed a teraforming process.
Even better, NASA estimates that when the magnetic shield is set up, the cessation of radiation bombardment on mars will cause a chain reaction of heat rising and atmosphere restauration, even potentially forming liquid water on the surface.
NASA wants to launch such a field by 2050.

To solve five of the problems of Mars colonization.

1. Psychological evaluations. This is the most important part of the colonization effort. I would not want mentally unstable people and or incompetent people to colonize Mars. I think a potentially unique solution that we might just have in our lifetimes is direct neural interfaces. It could potentially lead to curing various mental illnesses and for maintaining people's sanity in space colonization efforts or for more efficient and superior education.

2. Nuclear power. If we ever develop nuclear fusion, it would make Mars colonization much easier as water can be easily broken down into oxygen and hydrogen, two things needed to ensure our astronauts can breathe, and terraform mars, and hydrogen which would fuel our rockets, land, and air vehicles, as well as our nuclear fusion reactors. We will need these if we are to terraform mars later. Plus fissionable elements are rare, expensive, and highly toxic.

3. Terraforming. Since Mars has a lot less gravity than earth does, we would need to encase Mars in a kind of airtight, world spanning greenhouse with orbital rings surrounding it to still allow for space travel and trade. This trade could also facilitate faster terraforming as the water ice and nitrogen brought from space. If we want to make Mars more like earth, we would have to make it more geologically active too. For this we could potentially funnel waste heat from our power plants and fusion reactors into the core of the planet. The planet itself could act as an impressive heat sink.

4. Mining. Dumping waste heat into the planet itself to stimulate geological activity would also strengthen mars' magnetic field which would mean that heavy radiation shielding could be mostly eliminated. Add to that reheating mars' interior could also induce convection currents that would draw up all kinds of valuable minerals and ores that we could process for other purposes, which would leave asteroid miners to gather resources for other, more ambitious projects. Plus, mining on a lower-gravity planet is much easier than on a higher-gravity one.

5. Lower gravity adaptation. As far as we can tell, antigravity and or paragravity (gravity control) is simply impossible so we might have to go the transhumanist, augumementation route to adapt to changing gravity. We could start by creating a nanotech based process for making our bones and muscles resistant to degradation and or much denser and stronger. Plus we could go a step further and make ourselves much more resilient to cosmic radiation by increasing the amount of melanin in our skin or by other means.

14psi isn't really a great pressure difference my dudes. It's actually not much at all and the same methods used for other spacecraft will be applicable in this case. Additionally, you can run lower pressures if compensating with a higher concentration of O2. For example the command module on the Apollo missions ran about 5psi of pure O2 in it's early days. Of course going this extreme is a fire hazard but we can certainly reduce the internal/external pressure differential on a permanent basis by some amount and thus further reducing mechanical stress on habitats.

I think all of the problems are solved by skipping the epic terraforming of Mars (which potentially can take millenia to complete, and will never be perfect for human habitation; not without genetic manipulation, and even then, it's a rather dubious endeavour) and jump directly to the construction of O'Neill Cylinder Space Habitats. They can be dialed up to any gravitational value (g) that we like (by centrifugal force), allow us to control the enviroment entirely and since we are standing inside a pressurized cylinder (on metal, dirt and whatever we need to recreate Earth' climate at a small scale in an O'Neill Cylinder), we are perfectly safe from deadly radiation (a surrounding asteroid shell might be a good idea anyway - just in case). Mars, if terraformed, might give us the living area of a bit less than the surface area of russia - but if we break it apart to get the raw materials for building O'Neill Cylinders, we will get several deca-millions worth of earth living area (we're talking about quadrillions of people). No terraformed planet can rival that amount of living area, protection and comfort - no matter how close to Earth it eventually might be terraformed to.

Terraforming planets will probably be a prestige project for the wealthy, because in light of those space habitats, which are cheaper and easier to build, terraforming is a huge waste of raw materials. In comparison it will never be economically viable and takes ages to get it even vaguely habitable. I know people won't like that, but Space Habitat's like the O'Neill Cylinder are just the logical way to colonize space effectively (another type would be a McKendree Cylinder - a truly huge structure that can harbor the population of an entire continent; millions of people and many times more massive than an O'Neill Cylinder).

In a couple of centuries, most people will live in space habitats - and they will regard the concept of living on actual planets, as being rather odd and quirky.

We actually don't know the biological effects of reduced gravity, since we've never experienced it (outside of a couple of days on the moon). We won't know until we live on Mars for a couple of years, or unless we set up a spinning space habitat that simulates Mars gravity and live in that for a couple of years.
Another problem that we will need to overcome is the radiation exposure while flying to Mars, and from Mars back to Earth. We will either need our spacecraft to have lots of shielding (which will make them very heavy), or to accept increased cancer rates for astronauts.

When the English first settled in America, it was a complete disaster. 80% of the people who made up the first Jamestown settlement died within the first year, due to disease, and starvation. However, this first settlement would lead to both the rise of the British Empire, and the creation of the United States of America, two of the greatest superpowers the world has seen within the past 2 centuries.

The same will go for Mars (and Venus as well). It is possible to make the Red Planet a second home for humanity, but it'll be a long, LONG time before people will be able to go outside for a nice picnic, and it'll take a LOT of sacrifices in the beginning the lay the foundation for this future world.
